dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: Out west where the sun descends gloriously over desolate mountains. A sense of timeless and incorruptible beauty if you ignore the TWANG of the MUSIC, the SPUTTER of the TRACTOR, the ZAPS, the THWACKS... and something else... ... MEN'S VOICES.   Garrulous with drink, fraternity and amusement. We PAN DOWN TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man, JOSE, is on the roof, wrestling with a rickety satellite dish, stringing wire, trying to get it to work. (We get glimpses of him throughout the scene as he struggles with what is assuredly a pirate operation.) Four of six floodlights nailed to the roof cast pools of yellow into the gathering darkness. ROY "TIN CUP" McAVOY stands under the swarm of moths crowding the brightest light, hitting golf balls. THWOCK...! Launching them, really, into the deepening night. There's a beer between his legs. Behind him: A group of men forms a semicircle, facing away from Tin Cup. These men are the range regulars: CURT, CLINT, EARL, and DEWEY. Each man has money in one hand and his preferred libation in the other. They're all looking back and forth between the bug lights hung on the back wall, and muttering what sounds like bets to: ROMEO POSAR -- a smaller man, he stands at the center of the group with a handful of cash. Romeo is a part-time bookie and full-time driving range man. Born across the river in Mexico, Romeo is Tin Cup's caddie, confidante, best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, all bets are down! Their eyes rivet on the bug lights, edgy, hopeful, until... ZAP! A BUG is ELECTROCUTED. And Dewey cheers triumphantly while the other regulars mutter curses about how they woulda, coulda, shoulda bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one is the winner! Dewey has the winner. Pays five to two! Romeo quickly pays Dewey and more quickly takes money fro the losers. It's fast-paced, inane, time-killing gambling. Tin Cup looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you shitheels ever get bored? The regulars flap dismissive palms and mutter in the negative as they turn back to Romeo and the action at the bug lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'Cuz I got a riddle. Tin Cup leads the regulars inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup holds court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes about two ounces of brains to figure it out. Anyone think they got a brain with two ounces of brains in it? The regulars silently look at each other, reluctant to reveal the heft of their brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Chrissakes, boys! A little self-confidence from the players' gallery. We ain't talking long division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (timidly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much we gotta lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to liven things up, Earl? That's a hell of an idea. Say everyone puts in twenty bucks and the pot goes to whoever solves the riddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to get the riddle, Tin Cup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) Dewey. I'm the one asking the riddle. I already know the answer. I don't getta guess. Although... We could say if I get to five hundred bounces and no one gets the riddle, I get the pot. And I know what you're thinking. It's an impossible riddle. Well, It's not. It's an easy riddle. And if somehow by the grace of fluke luck I win, and you all don't agree it was an easy riddle, hell, I'll refund your money. EARL, CLINT & ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in... We're in... Count us in... etc... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, a man's driving down the road with his son and they get in a crash. Two ambulances come and take the man and his son to different hospitals. Son goes into the operating room, the doctor looks at him and says, 'I can't operate on this boy. He's my son.' How's that possible? (beat) The clock's ticking boys... Tin Cup begins bouncing a ball on the face of his wedge. EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father didn't sneak back in, right? He's still at the other hospital? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't 'Star Trek,' Earl.   No one beamed him aboard. That eliminates the most plausible theory in their minds. The men think harder. EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... if the father married the son's daughter -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a family riddle, Earl.   Think clean thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regulars puzzle some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us a little hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor's a woman. All heads turn to take in the arrival of:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY GRISWOLD
dialogues.text: Standing just inside the door -- she's a fresh-faced beauty in her early thirties, and she's got all new everything the sport of golf requires: new bag, new clubs, new shoes, new clothes, new visor... she looks like she stepped out of an ad in Golf Digest. And all the men are asking themselves the same question: what's she doing here? The silence invites Molly to supply the riddle's answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor is the son's mother. Feminists pose the riddle to reveal how deeply our sexual stereotypes run. (directly to Tin Cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you're a feminist? Tin Cup misses the ball he's been bouncing, breaking the spell. The regulars wait for Tin Cup's response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I've been called a lot of things -- but no one's ever saddled me with that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might try being saddled sometime -- the smell of leather, the sting of a whip... The regulars snicker, enjoying her one-upmanship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a humble golf pro...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Roy McAvoy the golf pro? I pictured something... different. I have a seven o'clock lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had a Doctor Griswold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at seven. They hurry out to the range, Tin Cup oblivious to his gaffe. And the regulars gather to look out the window --

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: To the range, where Molly is stretching and Tin Cup is discreetly waving to the regulars to get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lesson begins. Tin Cup can be slightly condescending in these situations, though she's got him a little wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing you gotta learn about this game, Doc, is it ain't about hitting a little white ball into some yonder hole. It's about inner demons and self-doubt and human frailty and overcoming all that crap. So... what kinda doctor'd you say you were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a psychologist -- in layman's terms call me a neo-Jungian, post- modern Freudian, holistic secularist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. She begins unpacking one of her bags, pulling out every golf gimmick on the market -- swing aid straps to pull your elbows together, a ball pendulum that hangs from your hat, a metal contraption for your feet, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inner demons and human frailty are my life's work. I used to practice in El Paso but I've moved here now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ordered these from the Golf Channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares in disbelief as she tries to wriggle into some of this stuff. He's enchanted and dismayed. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stuff's a waste of money. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure there are excesses and repetitions here, but I believe in the gathering of knowledge and I figured, well, there must be some truths about the golf swing illustrated by these devices -- and that you'd help me sort through it. She stands there with contraptions coming from every limb. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have dozens of golf videotapes, too... And a golf watch. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated, impatient) Take it off. All of it. Now! You're a smart woman, for Chrissakes -- don't you know the work of charlatans when you see it? She deposits all the golf gimmick devices in a pile. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I can always tell when someone is lying to himself, but I'm quite susceptible and frequently wrong when that person lies to me. (pointing to the pile of devices)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stuff cost me over 200 dollars -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's 200 dollars of shit... He tees a ball, hands Molly her driver and steps back. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.   Take a swing. Molly takes a pitty-pat swing and whiffs, and mutters under her breath with the ease of a longshoreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, fuck... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you talk like a golfer -- Molly unloads a mighty second swing. The club head bounces off the mat. The ball sits untouched. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fuck...' 'Shit...' these are highly technical golf terms and you're using them on your first lesson -- this is promising. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, wise ass, show me. Tin Cup takes the club from Molly, motions for her to step back, tees up a ball, and rockets a drive into the night. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that. He hands her back the club and tees up another ball. Molly just looks at him. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive. Y'know, I tend to process things verbally. Can you break down into words how you did that? Tin Cup takes a deep breath -- this is his speech. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'What is the golf swing?' -- by Roy McAvoy. (beat) The golf swing is a poem. TIN CUP (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes a love sonnet and sometimes a Homerian epic -- it is organic and of a piece, yet it breaks down into elegant stanzas and quatrains. The critical opening phrase of this song is the grip, in which the hands unite to form a single unit by the simple overlap of the smallest finger... (displays grip) ... held lightly, a conductor's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: baton. (starts swing) Lowly and slowly the clubhead is pulled back, led into position not by the hands but the body which turns away from the target, shifting to the right side without shifting balance. Tempo is everything, perfection unobtainable, as the body coils, now to the top of the swing, in profound equilibrium. And then a slight hesitation, a nod to the gods...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A nod to the gods?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: To the gods, yes... that he is fallible. As the weight shifts back to the left pulled now by powers inside the earth -- it's alive, this swing, a living sculpture -- and down through contact, always down, into terra firma, striking the ball crisply -- with character -- a tuning fork goes off in your heart, your balls -- such a pure feeling is the well-struck golf shot -- And then the follow through to finish, always on line -- The reverse 'C' of the Golden Bear, the steelworker's power and brawn of Carl Sandburg's Arnold Palmer, the da Vinci of Hogan, the unfinished symphony of Roy McAvoy.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What?    What's unfinished?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: I have a short follow through -- my swing can look unfinished.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Some say it's because that's the best way to play through the winds of West Texas... and some say it's because I never finish anything. You can decide. The point is every finishing position is unique as if that is the signature left to the artist, the warrior athlete who,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: finally and thereby, has asserted his oneness with and power over the universe by willing a golf ball to go where he wants and how and when, because that is what the golf swing is about... (finally) It is about gaining control of your life, and letting go at the same time. Molly stares back, exhausted and intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez Louise... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is only one other acceptable theory of how to hit a golf ball. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid to ask. What's the other theory? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grip it and rip it. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While I appreciate your poetic sensibility, Mr. McAvoy -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Roy, Molly... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Dr. Griswold... MOLLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy... but at this point I think I'm more of the 'grip it and rip it' school. Hand me the driver. Tin Cup does.   She tees it up. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waggle it, Doc, don't forget to waggle. (as she stares at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waggle... the club head... (shows her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it's a little relaxing ritual... She waggles the club head, then takes the club back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the Big Dog eat! She stops, lets the club fall. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Big Dog? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver, the number one wood -- MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's metal. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, woods are metal -- don't worry about it -- and the driver's known as the Big Dog and I'm just saying to turn him loose, let 'er rip, let the Big Dog eat! MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. She swings.   Tops the ball.   It goes ten feet. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is, without a doubt, the stupidest, silliest, most idiotic grotesquery masquerading as a game that has ever been invented. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Yes, ma'am, that's why I love it. (beat) And if you hit one good shot -- if that tuning fork rings in your loin -- you can't wait to get back. She cracks one dead solid perfect out into the night.   I felt great and she knows it. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the Big Dog ate something. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the tuning fork ring in your loin? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go that far. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always quit on a good shot. We'll call that lesson number one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) ... and if ya wouldn't mind paying me in cash -- there's a little I.R.S. situation I'm dealing with
MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're such a legendary striker of the golf ball as everyone says, then why are you, at your age, out here in the middle of nowhere operating a barely solvent establishment, ducking the I.R.S., collecting a few pathetic dollars to buy your next sixpack -- when you're capable of so much more? Her speech is delivered without judgement or rancor, so matter of factly that he's disarmed. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I'm chocked full of inner demons? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're chocked full of bullshit -- (cheerily) Same time next week? She heads off to the parking lot.    He stares. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you mean I should try 'being saddled' sometime? TIN CUP (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you being literal or was that some kind of Freudian type deal? Molly? Doctor? (beat) What kind of saddle?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: As she walks into the West Texas night.    She smiles, enjoying Tin Cup's confusion. Tin Cup just stares into the night, holding his cash, unt JOSE'S VOICE ECHOES down from the roof. JOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it!   Esta bien!    The flag is up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup enters, cash in hand, as the regulars all gather excitedly around the TV monitor now coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A class act there, boys -- probably the first actual `lady type' female ever seen on these premises --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, boss -- we got the Corpus Christi dog track on the dish --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is yer dead mortal cinch lock bet with Do-reen. Everyone's glued to the set. A greyhound race comes on from a remote Texas track on the gulf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free money, boys, what does Doreen know about the fine art of Greyhound breeding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All she knows is she likes the three dog 'cause his name is Pride of Odessa 'cause she's from Odessa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get ready for Oddessa-lation, boys. How deep we in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave her twenty to one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only fifteen to one on the toteboard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I got every other dog in the race. I'm just getting even with Doreen -- I'm not trying to clean her clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how much you stand to lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousand. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicky) Hundred. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said to shoot the wad. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said get even, Pod. I didn't say shoot the wad. We better see that three dog rolling on his ass. All eyes on the monitor -- the dogs break. EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except... if he breaks slow, he won't get creamed... The starting box opens -- "THERE GOES THE RABBIT" -- the three dog breaks slow and trails down the front stretch. REGULARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three dog's dying, T.C.... easy money... (etc.) The one dog veers wide, going into the escape turn, annihilating the field. Dogs fly ass over teakettle like bowling pins, and -- REGULARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. The three dog clears the pileup, untouched, hugging the rail. It has a ten length lead as it moves down the backstretch and past the toteboard. The race is over -- the three dog wins. Deathly silence. Somebody flips OFF the TV. Finally, in a lame attempt to lighten the moment, Romeo speaks -- ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Roy, you were saying you felt a little flutter for this doctor lady? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I was saying that... just before I was interrupted by... bankruptcy -- a development that the 'Doctor Lady,' as you call her,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: will consider utterly predictable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marquee advertises: EXOTIC DANCERS/STEAK $4.00. parking lot is full of pickup trucks and beer cans. Tin Cup and Romeo head toward the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost everything, boss! We owe Doreen twelve thousand bucks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I been dating too many big-haired blondes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them big-haired blondes are a lot smarter 'n us... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... how we gonna pay her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You underestimate me, Romes. Romeo doesn't realize the truth in his own response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bad habit I picked up from knowing you so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tin Cup, Doreen's looking for ya --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she is... They enter the strip joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nearly-NAKED DANCER on stage to a lot of whooping cowboys. Tin Cup moves in this world with ease and something that passes for grace. Everyone knows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tin Cup, haven't seen ya in three days!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy man, Courtenay, busy man -- As they pass the stage, even the Naked Dancer interrupts her moment with a bunch of guys offering dollar bills --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup!     Hi, sweetie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, honey -- lookin' sweet... And backstage they go, easily waved through by another bouncer. They come up to a dressing room door. And knock. A voice from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That better be you, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP AND ROMEO
dialogues.text: enter this holy of holies with complete familiarity. And there she is -- DOREEN, 35, at least, the classic chesty, hippie, big-wigged Texas goddess. She's older than the other girls, and more experienced in every way. She's smoking a cigarette and finishing up the touches on her stripper's outfit. Tin Cup and Romeo stand at her beckoning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doreen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking particularly lovely this evening -- This is nicer than the leopard suit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the horseshit, guys. So... the one and two dogs always run wide and the three dog always breaks slow, so I figure there's gonna be a big ol' pile of fur at the turn and the three dog's gonna tiptoe around it and walk on home... I was right. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me twelve thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We going to pay you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup squirms as Doreen babbles a bit. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're going to pay me. DOREEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiring her own outfit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know I finally got rid of the leopard suit thing -- it was so retro, y'know... it's not easy being a post-modern stripper... (beat) So... twelve big ones? Tin Cup finally digs into his coat pocket and produces some official-looking papers. He hands them to her. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. With equity and inventory it's worth twelve grand... more or less. Doreen leans forward to examine the papers.    She looks Tin Cup with surprise. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how you think you can settle up? By deeding me your driving range? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only on condition you don't sell right away, and me'n Romeo keep our jobs. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the world would I want with your stupid driving range? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equity, inventory, cash flow... not to mention an enhanced stature in the community, and prepaid membership in the Salome Chamber of Commerce. For a moment, Doreen can only stare dumbly at Tin Cup, caught off guard by this unexpected turn of fortune. Then she starts to consider the idea more seriously. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your labor costs? (off no response from Tin Cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Payroll, Roy. What do you pay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: your help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see... the tractor kid gets five bucks an hour. Romeo, he gets ten cash --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you pay yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myself? Doreen nods in a way Tin Cup finds threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hit golf balls all day... when you're not breaking for beers or corn dogs or to gather the guys and lay bets on which crow flies off the fence next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're referring to my managerial salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm referring to every nickel you snatch out of the till and every bag of beer nuts you lift from the rack, is what I'm referring to. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say it's worth ten and you still owe me two. She smiles, he sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup parks his big old red Cadillac convertible out front. He goes around to the trunk, opens it, takes out his golf clubs, and carries them into the pawn shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's domicile, parked near a slow-moving river. The red Cadillac is parked out front next to Romeo's Mercury Comet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with horror, inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Winnebago)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hocked your golf clubs?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup sits on the couch, swigging Maalox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still got two grand to pay off. And I can't see my new salary of seven bucks an hour plus lessons getting it done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your clubs are your livelihood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the hood ain't too lively at the moment. A CAR HORN SOUNDS from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever it is, tell 'em I'm in Houston on business. Romeo opens the door, and steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Simms!   What you doing in town? Romeo steps outside to greet Simms.   Warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo and Simms under the awning.   A spiffy new car parked nearby. DAVID SIMMS, 38, looking every bit like the successful tour pro he is... Payne Stewart to Tin Cup's Maynard G. Krebs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo! It's been awhile.    Is Tin Cup around? Romeo is evasive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on business in Houston... You supposed to be out playin' on the golf tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed) Well, you tell him I'm in town for my big charity best-ball tournament, and I got a spot for him when he comes back from... whatever. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a spot for Tin Cup?   I thought you hated him. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo! You wound me. I'm fond of the guy, going way back to our days at University of Houston, when we won all those titles together. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he carried you on his back. Simms won't be drawn into this adolescent competition -- he's too comfortable with himself and his success. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have much craft back then -- just a little native ability. Roy's a great ball- striker.... ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you here? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to win my own tournament, and he can help me if we can manage to behave like grownups together. Tell him that. Tin Cup suddenly appears in the doorway. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the catch? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no catch. I put together a tournament with an elite field and a half-million dollar purse, and I'm tired of seeing all the money head out of town. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then make more birdies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you on my team. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't that friendly a guy... SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're playing Cottonwood where you once shot fifty-nine, where you can shoot sixty-five in your sleep 'cuz you know every bump on every fairway, every subtle break on every green -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily) You an' me -- SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me an' you -- like the old days. Tin Cup can't quite believe this offer from his old nemesis but there aren't many options out there. He grabs Simms's hand and starts pumping it, gushing with enthusiasm. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well, put 'er there, partner! These two homeboys are gonna show the world what golf in West Texas is all about! SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Roy. I didn't mean I want you to play with me. I just want you to caddie for me, read my putts, club me, that kinda stuff. Tin Cup wilts like a time-lapsing daisy.   His hand falls free of Simms's. Words fail him. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself, blankly) Caddie? Me? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't bring a guy in off the street to play in my tournament. It's a big-time event, corporate sponsors, thirty dollar tickets... I got a network to cover -- ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: outraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy off the street, he could kick your ass on that golf course. Like he kicked your ass in junior golf. Like he kicked your ass in college. Like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay you a hundred for the loop, five percent of any earnings --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell outta here! Take your goddamn color coordinated corporate sponsored soul and get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, just thought I'd offer you some work... Simms heads to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take the job. Simms nods in agreement, and exits.    Tin Cup stands the with Romeo, feeling humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMS
dialogues.text: drives away down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man stands for everything I hate in life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like... success?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banners and galleries and concession tents create the atmosphere of a polite circus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY MAYFAIR putts out on the 16th green to polite applause.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COTTONWOOD GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: The two twosomes tee off and the caddies follow, including Tin Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A leader board reads:   SIMMS/STADLER -10, MICKELSON/ MCCORD -8. A giant gallery lines the fairway and rings the distant green which is fronted by a lake, as: STADLER hits a three wood toward the green -- the BALL PLUNKS in the middle of the lake. The GALLERY GROANS. Stadler just shrugs to Simms, as if to say, "I thought I had enough club."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I told you, it was more'n you had in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... I had to go for it after your caddy said he could get home from here. Simms swivels his head around to look at Tin Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could. Simms looks away, at the shot he's facing: a two hundred fifteen yard carry over water. He looks back at Tin Cup, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta hand it to you, Roy. For fifteen holes you've seemed to grasp the concept here: I'm trying to win and your job is to help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five percent of your earnings does numb the gag reflex. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the seven iron.   I'm laying up. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can make that shot. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smart play's to lay up. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These fans didn't pay thirty bucks to watch a tour star lay up on a short par five. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sitting on a two shot lead with three to go, and my partner's in his pocket. Suddenly, par's a good number. Gimme the seven Iron. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. You're going for the green. These fans paid good money to see golf shots they can't hit, not golf shots they feel shitty about themselves for having to hit. Simms reaches for the seven iron.   Tin Cup clamps a hand over the club. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen years on tour and you're still a pussy. Hit the fucking one iron, Dave. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen years in a driving range and you still think this game's about your testosterone count. Simms removes Tin Cup's hand from the seven iron and grabs the club, stepping up to address the ball. Tin Cup mutters to the gallery. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-fifteen to carry, and the tour star's laying up. And the remark summons gallery voices suddenly urging Simms to go for the green. Simms motions for Tin Cup, as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: if reconsidering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you're gonna editorialize, do it on the other side of the ropes. I got no qualms about firing your ass right here, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire me?   Hell, I should fire you. Simms steps back to his ball with the seven iron, and: 16   Stadler's still standing back where he hit the shot the lake. MICKELSON and GARY McCORD, the other team in the pairing, are there with him. Romeo, Stadler's caddie, stands just behind them. McCORD (to Mickelson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you could knock it on from here, I'm just saying that caddie's been drinking muddy water if he thinks he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can. All the players look at Romeo as: Simms dumps his seven iron shot safely down in front of the water to a smattering of polite applause. Simms tosses the club back to his bag as Tin Cup retrieves the divot. And:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave!   We in a hurry? Simms looks several yards back where Stadler is still standing with McCord and Mickelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I just bet McCord and Mickelson that your caddie could knock it on from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to win a tournament, pardo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.    But I'm getting five to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ANNOUNCER from the GOLF CHANNEL looks at the monitor where a hand-held camera is picking up Stadler motioning Tin Cup over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From two-fifty from a snarly lie, over water, on national TV, with no warmup... I'd give ten to one to a tour pro.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO COURSE
dialogues.text: Stadler, McCord, and Mickelson are smiling at the bet. This is golf. But Simms snarls at being challenged. Stadler drops a ball in the rough for Tin Cup to hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here ya go.   Take a hack at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balls versus brains, Roy. You hit that shot, just keep walking, 'cuz your ass is fired. Tin Cup mulls over the warning, as: STADLER, McCORD, MICKELSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Roy!    Your fans are calling! Stadler waves his arms to summon a cheer from the gallery Tin Cup puts down Simms's golf bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you gonna fire me in front of all these people? Especially when I knock it on the green. And he heads over to where Stadler and the others stand waiting.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: PETER KOSTIS, with a hand mike, following the group, begins to describe the extraordinary event unfolding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems like the Charity Tournament is taking a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: break for a side bet, here -- Gary McCord moves toward the camera and takes the microphone. McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I've done a little background here -- this unfolding disaster's a driving range pro named Roy McAvoy, who everyone calls Tin Cup. Locals claim he he was a pretty good college lick and knocked around the mini-tours... 20   Tin Cup steps up to hit the shot.   McCord lowers hi voice. McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but I guarantee you, he's about to suffer brain arrest. He's thinking about the cameras and the gallery and the water, and all that gray matter between his ears is turning to goo... and incidentally, Stadler's got it booked at ten to one... Tin Cup swings, and: 21   The CAMERA PICKS UP the ball arching high and true o the club. It lands on the green. The CROWD ROARS... and the roar becomes deafening as the ball rolls three feet from the pin. KOSTIS AND McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not that good... he's definitely not that good... (etc.) 22   BACK TO the course -- a scuffle's breaking out. David Simms helping some guy over the gallery rope. Simms walks the guy back to his golf bag... and now Tin Cup understands what's happening, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a hike, Roy -- the loop's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't fire me. How can you fire me? I just knocked it stiff from two fifty. Gimme that bag. Tin Cup reaches for the bag. The guy holds onto it. They wrestle briefly, as Simms sighs with fatigue and looks for a marshal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security! Tin Cup gives up wrestling when he sees a couple marshals approaching. He turns his anger on Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just hit the shot that took you out of the money. Welcome to life on the tour. Tin Cup goes after the bag again. The guy still hangs on. The marshals arrive, and begin to wrestle with Tin Cup. He goes berserk... a WWF battle royal.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: Sports highlights.    Introducing "Sports Machine" with George Michaels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally Sports Machine brings you a bizarre incident... A brief highlight of Tin Cup, going crazy, wrestling with the marshals and replacement caddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving range pro, Roy `Tin Cup' McAvoy... MALE LAUGHTER greets the shot, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tin Cup!    You made the news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Regulars crowd under the TV on the wall above the till, hooting at what they just saw. Tin Cup is nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo scoops balls into wire buckets from the garbage can of water where the balls are washing. Tin Cup sits on a bench, alternately swigging cheap whiskey and Maalox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had it all to do over, I'd still hit that shot. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods with neither rancor nor irony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look comes over your face, you would bury yourself alive to prove you can handle a shovel. Tin Cup looks over at Romeo for signs of an implied pejorative. But Romeo's just washing and scooping balls... and looking badly in need of perspective. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why I'd still hit that shot? Now Romeo looks over... and he decides that Tin Cup is the one in need of perspective. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cuz it's the only way you can beat David Simms. 'Cuz you never got over that he is on tour and you are not. 'Cuz you get that look on your face... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... (pauses, adding weight to his thoughts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hit it again because that shot was a defining moment. And when a defining moment comes along you define the moment or the moment defines you. I did not shrink from the challenge. I rose to it. Romeo nods, holding his peace. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1981, Fort Washington Golf Club, Fresno, California, final round of the Tour Qualifying School... Tin Cup cringes at the memory, then moves for the high ground. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was playing to win. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A defining moment when you tried to hit the same impossible cut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: three wood into the wind from a hilly lie -- four in a row out of bounds -- until you finally pulled it off and tapped in for a thirteen. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a twelve woulda got you on the tour! That was a defining moment and the definition was shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greatness courts failure, Romeo. That's why most people, in their whole lives, never ever reach for the brass ring, never know when to dig deep and try for the impossible shot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right about that, boss, but sometimes... sometimes... par is good enough to win. Tin Cup tosses down another Maalox cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parking lot full of the usual suspects as a BUMP AND GRIND VERSION of "YELLOW ROSE OF TEXAS" floods outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doreen dances in a yellow rose outfit, a more classic strip look than her protegees.

dialogues.speaker: ROW OF DOLLAR BILLS
dialogues.text: held aloft by the eager locals in the front row... and then a handful of papers held aloft by one Roy McAvoy, also in the front row. Doreen dances over and picks the papers from his hand, reading them as she dances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DieHard/West Texas Calcutta, the Duvall County Boys Club Pro/ Scratch, Woody's Steak House One Club Scramble... what do I want with all these entry forms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a business proposition. I'm offering you my winnings from all them tournaments this summer. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In exchange for what? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My driving range back. She dances away from him, not exactly sold on the idea. She dances back to him, reclines a leg on the partition, and moves her face opposite his. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, I'm not as dumb as my hair makes me look. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't all strictly minor league. One of 'em pays almost two grand! She twirls off.    He chases her, beer and entries in han TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait, Doreen. You gotta do the math, and you gotta look at how good I'm playing. I hit the shot of the tournament at the best-ball. They put it on national TV. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does that tell you? The MUSIC comes to an END.   The club is momentarily silent. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) And what does that tell you? DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It tells me you took an unauthorized day off. Next time it happens, you're fired. In the meantime, I'm putting in a time clock. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not punching in no time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: clock like some working stiff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup punches the new time clock which is located under the awning near the ball wash. KACHUNK goes the TIME CLOCK as he hurries outside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and there he finds Molly, waiting on the tee with her driver and a bucket of balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McAvoy, I can appreciate that you have a fairly laid-back, relaxed lifestyle -- but I have hours to keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A former paramour once ascribed my fluid sense of time to being born under the sign of Pisces -- something about floating through the universe -- He tees a ball for her and steps back.   She's staring at him, half-amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You amuse me, Roy. But I'm the only woman in America born after World War II who thinks astrology is a crock of shit. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's see if the Big Dog'll eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waggling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set up to the ball like I showed you last time. Molly addresses the shot.    Her stance is rigid, overly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mechanical.   Tin Cup winces.    But she looks terrific. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit trying to wring that club's neck, Molly. Show it a little warmth and compassion... He moves around behind her to reposition her shoulders. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, this game's about trust and touch and letting go. So while I'm subtly enhancing your technical prospects, why don't you tell me all about your personal life... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's none of your fucking business, Roy. Tin Cup's hands move down to square her hips.    He's discreet and professional. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend's a golfer -- that's my bet -- and he's why you're taking this game up. Hell, I probably even know him -- SIMMS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off her ass, Roy. And, as Tin Cup's hands recoil in alarm... DAVID SIMMS steps onto the range. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simms) Hi, sweetie... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not him...

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Crushed and bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMS
dialogues.text: A killer smile. The man is absolutely at ease with his own success and charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow paces across the drape in the lighted window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's taking her to Miami for the fucking Doral! How am I supposed to compete with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo ponders Tin Cup's dilemma from the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you are having a bad week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must think I'm such a nothing, such a loser... a lousy driving range pro living in a Winnebago, making five bucks an hour plus lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't know you live in a Winnebago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she sure as hell knows I ain't taking her to no Doral for massages and mimosas all weekend. I gotta do something with my life. He reflects deeply while Romeo shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta rise to a level worthy of the women that think I'm a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you could go out and win The Open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing, as if jarred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, that idea has promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: We talking about the same tournament? The U.S. Open? The Biggest golf tournament in the world?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Not just the biggest golf Tournament in the world; the most democratic.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: I mean it's open. Anyone's got a shot at it. You just gotta get past a local and a sectional qualifier, and unlike Doral or Colonial or the A.T.T., they can't keep you out. They can't ask you if you're a garbageman or a bean- picker or a driving range pro whose check is signed by a stripper. You qualify, you're in.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: And then you pay out of your own pocket to go there and get all nervous and intimidated --

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Who's intimidated? I just told you I'm gonna win the damn thing!

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: You don't got the game.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: I got every shot in the book.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I said you don't got the game. The mental game. The head game.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: You suggesting I err on the side of excess?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: You always go out to shoot zero. Sometimes you pull it off. But you can't play like that at the Open. You win by taking what the course gives you. You win by being humble, which you aren't, and patient, which you never will

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: be. Tin Cup comes over to the couch, sits down, and puts an arm around Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since you're the authority, How'd you like to teach me how to be what I ain't and never will be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't ever listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time'll be different.   I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, man. Right now you don't even got the money to get your clubs out of hock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... my sticks may be in a pawn shop, but I got a rake and a hoe at the range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expensive cars in the parking lot -- A putting green in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK OF MERCEDES
dialogues.text: The trunk opens. A set of expensive golf clubs is removed by a wealthy looking guy, BOONE, 40'S. He turns to face Tin Cup and Romeo who is reaching into the trunk of Roy's Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight -- you're going to play me for four hundred dollars with those? Romeo removes an old golf bag from the trunk. It contains a rake, a hoe, a baseball bat, and assorted garden tools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll give ya two a side... I got the title to my car as collateral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in that piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cuz you think of it as transportation, Boone. Think of it as bragging rights. Think of yourself sitting around the bar crowing to your buddies about the Cadillac you won off Tin Cup McAvoy. (the real kicker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll forget all about the Winnebago you lost to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boone addresses the ball on the first tee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mullies, no gimmes, no bumping the ball -- And he rips a drive down the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nutted it. Tin Cup selects the baseball bat from his golf bag. Romeo hands him a pink ball and Tin Cup shows it to Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be playing a Pink Lady today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little pink fag ball supposed to rattle me? Tin Cup moves over to the tee markers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless I knock it by you. And he tosses up the Pink Lady and fungoes it long and straight down the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup stops at his ball, and looks twenty yards back to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where Boone has arrived with his caddie at his drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, I caught this thing way the Hell on the toe. Boone knocks an iron onto the edge of the green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive for show, putt for dough, big shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Romeo? Boone was being profound! He has revealed to me the essential mystery of golf! Drive for show, putt for dough... (holds out a palm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louisville Slugger, please. Boone's a little rattled by Tin Cup's insouciance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got Boone shakin' already -- (studying the approach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front left bunker's your best angle to the pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling his shot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front left bunker -- plugged lie. He tosses up the ball and fungoes a lazy fly ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boone gazes with malicious delight at Tin Cup's ball, buried in the front left bunker. He watches Tin Cup take the hoe from Romeo and move down into the trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see a legitimate swing. No scooping. Tin Cup holds up a hand like a gallery marshal requesting silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand, please.     Gallery, please, stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He addresses the ball, choking down on the hoe, positioning the blade at an odd angle. He hacks at the ball with an unorthodox chopping motion. The ball pops up in the air, lands on the green, releases and rolls up a foot from the hole. Boone's jaw drops. Tin Cup hit an impossible shot with utter ease and facility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll finish. Tin Cup trades Romeo the shovel for the rake, takes the pin out of the hole, and pool cues the putt home. Par. Boone looks at his own sixty-foot putt and he knows he's just been had... utterly, embarrassingly, and thoroughly. Without a word he counts four hundred dollars from his roll and drops it on the green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell off my course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Romeo emerge, Romeo carrying T.C.'s sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, swami, your job is to teach me patience and humility, not to advise me on my love life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. My job is to get your head straight so you can qualify for The Open, much less win it. To get your head straight you got to forget about the doctor lady. They head up the street under a collonade toward Tin Cup's waiting Caddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all my thinking occurs below the belt. I actually stand for a few things beside where my next romantic interlude is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you got no problem telling the doctor lady you can't teach her no more till after the Open. Tin Cup blinks silently a moment, feeling slightly corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would make an issue of something that ain't an issue. Besides, I'm focused. Romeo responds with a Spanish curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, this is my quest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh... your quest... chingaso...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where I stand up for all the little guys everywhere who've had their fill of soulless robots like David Simms --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may be a soulless robot but he's a rich, happy soulless robot with a beautiful doctor lady girlfriend who's got you by the huevos -- (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, how is getting into the U.S. Open gonna change what she thinks about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll prove to her that I'm not who she thinks I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are who she thinks you are! Look, I don't bet on a horse with a hard-on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard-on?! Hard-on?! Hard-on?! Here, touch me, feel -- (as Tin Cup grabs himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel nothing! Here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey... shit... cool it... 39   Suddenly a convertible passes -- Simms and Molly, laughing, carefree, enjoying each other. The couple in the car doesn't see Tin Cup grabbing his crotch making a fool of himself on the sidewalk -- but Tin Cup and Romeo see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car disappears down the street. Tin Cup cools off, chilled, really -- and full of chagrin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... maybe I got a semi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doreen's on the phone, between shows, and is adamant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot give you time off to win The Open. I don't care if it's your 'quest'... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... or your 'destiny'... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... or any of those terms you vaguely remember from your Cliff Notes... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda treated me nicer when we were an item -- then maybe I wouldn't be such a nasty boss. G'bye, Roy -- I have a business to run. She hangs up and heads out on stage as the music calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup hangs up the phone and turns to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, ever since I let her dump my ass she just can't resist kicking me in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should treat her more like a lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After she ran off with that Dallas banker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did that after you let her dump you. It wouldn't kill you just once to tell her she's beautiful, she can dance, she's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sexy. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo... are you sweet on Doreen? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more'n you are for that doctor lady. A couple of deep sighs.   Two losers with fluttering hearts. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, Romeo, just great... just when I need you to be my friend and coach, you go get all gooey about one of my ex-girlfriends who just happens to be our boss. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody comes to me for help on their love life about women is already too far gone. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't recall asking you for advice. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women are tougher to figure out than a feathered one iron from a tight lie -- Suddenly a golf image relaxes them into their comfort zone. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually if you open the club face a hair and play it off your back foot -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Romeo... I wasn't really seeking golf tips... ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all I'm good for -- but you can count on me for that, at least. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far off the back foot? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout three balls... Silence.   Golf is so much easier than life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready to charge forth in pursuit of my mythic destiny and I can't get time off work to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no expert, but it seems to me that the `pursuit of a person's mythic destiny' is not the sort of thing that a person needs to get off a five dollar an hour job in order to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stuck. Buried. My life's a plugged lie in a kakuyi bunker with a tight pin position on a green with a stimp meter reading of thirteen. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need help. I need advice. I need counsel... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know no shrinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the doctor lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ask advice about the woman you're trying to hose from the woman you're trying to hose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hose?! Hose?! Get your mouth outta the gutter! This is a matter of the heart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's Caddy pulls up and   he gets out, goes to the front of a store that is now   a health services office. He looks around warily -- as   if someone might see him entering such a place -- and   ducks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the exit, "cool down" room, not the waiting room. Tin Cup sits nervously, he's slightly overdressed for the occasion. He looks childlike. The door to the inner office opens -- a woman comes out and sits down across from him. She's weeping uncontrollably. He stares. He fidgets. He's nervous, out of place. Finally Molly enters through the same door because she hears the crying. She sees Tin cup -- an awkward moment, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... I know... wait in there. Tin Cup slips into the main office while Molly consoles the weeping woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup is dutifully lying on the couch because he heard that's what you do. He stares at the ceiling. Molly enters and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy... are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do? I mean... to do it ... therapy... I mean, how do I start doing... it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In parlance you might understand, just kick back and let the Big Dog eat. He sighs and plunges in.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, let 'er rip... (deep breath) Suppose there's this guy. He's standing on the shore of a big, wide river. And the river's fulla all manner of disaster, like alligators and piranhas and currents and eddies, and most people won't even go down there to dip a toe. But on the other side of the river's a million dollars, and on this side of the river there's a rowboat. I guess my question's this: What would possess the guy on shore to swim for it?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He's an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: No. He's a hell of a swimmer, see. His problem's more like... why's he always gotta rise to the challenge?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He's a juvenile idiot.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: You don't understand what I mean by the river.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: We're talking about you and what you like to call your inner demons, Roy, that human frailty you like to blather about, not some mytho-poetic metaphor you come up with in a feeble and transparent effort to do yourself credit.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Y'mean you're gonna make me feel lousy? I came here to feel better -- what kinda therapy is this?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You don't have any inner demons. What you have is inner crapola, inner debris -- garbage, loose wires, horseshit in staggering amounts.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: I ain't just some jerk driving- range pro who drinks too much booze and eats too few vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You're being defensive -- cut to the chase and tell me why you're here.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Well... I'm smitten with a woman.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: That's good.   Is she smitten with you?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Have you asked her out?

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: She's seeing a guy. I don't know how serious it is, but the guy's a real horse's ass, in my opinion...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: If you shared your heart with this woman -- maybe asked her out to dinner -- then it would force these issues out in the open.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: I'm afraid she'll say no.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Ahh... so what you're saying is that all your speeches about swimming across the shark infested waters are really just about your golf game -- not about your personal life.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Christ, I didn't know we were gonna get into my personal life!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: This is therapy!

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Well, jeez, I know, but I didn't think it was that kind of therapy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you expecting?    Ann Landers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's rather simple. Those risks that you love to take on the golf course, the risks you talk so passionately and poetically about -- you need to apply those risks to your personal life with the same passion. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should ask this woman out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should risk coming right over the top and snap-hooking it out of bounds left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Risk hitting it a little thin and -- MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Godsakes, Roy, that's enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   Sorry. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'okay... (beat) Look, just walk up to this woman, wherever she is, look her in the eye with those big beautiful green eyes of yours, let down your guard and don't try to be smooth or cool or whatever -- just be honest and take the risk -- you can do it! Tin Cup rises with new confidence. He does several deep breathing exercises, trying to work up the courage. She stares at him. And he walks right up to her. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Griswold -- I think I'm in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: love with you. Molly is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the moment I first saw you I knew I was through with bar girls and strippers and motorcycle chicks, and when you started talking I was smitten and I'm smitten more every day I think about you -- and the fact that you know I'm full of crapola only makes you more attractive to me because usually I can bullshit people but I can't bullshit you and in addition, most women I'm thinking about how to get into their pants from Day One but with you I'm just thinking about how to get into your heart -- Molly was clue-less.   She just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (optimistically, proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, eh? So what about dinner and we can talk about `us' and if we have a future and how to drop that horse's ass boyfriend of yours -- MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, slow down -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I just hit a eight degree driver off a cart path here, I'm staring eagle in the face -- MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a terrible mistake! Tin Cup is knocked off his horse.   Into deep rough. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm acting from the heart so I can't make a mistake?! Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong.  Aw, shit... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am one horrible shrink... jeez... I didn't know you were talking about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would your advice have been different? She's frustrated and at a loss for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Session's over. You better leave. Crushed, Tin Cup heads to the door, stops and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna qualify for the U.S. Open and kick your boyfriend's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you think of me, you should know that your boyfriend hates old people, children, and dogs. He exits.   She just sits there.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The lone figure of Tin Cup stands on a tee, arching SEVEN IRONS -- THWOCK! -- into the night, serenaded by CRICKETS and the occasional BUG-LIGHT ZAPPING a fly. Romeo and the regulars stand behind Tin Cup observing approvingly. Tin Cup mutters something with every swing. It sounds like he's saying --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just before swinging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... Tin Cup hits another shot, totally focused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go with the doctor lady, boss? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she was a par three, I'd'a made a nine. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stroke and distance, eh? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, deep in concentration)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... Romeo backs off to let the man practice, and Clint asks: CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he saying? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills. His divots got to look like dollar bills. 'Course Moe Norman hits divots like bacon strips 'cuz he come over the top, but that's gettin' too technical for you. Clint turns and nods approvingly to the rest of the regulars. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that, boys? He's hitting dollar bills. Tightening his game. They murmur approval, but Earl catches Clint's eye and jerks his head at Tin Cup, indicating Clint isn't doing his job as group spokesman. Clint takes a step forward. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, something us shitheels want you to know, Tin Cup, is uh, well, we been to see Doreen, and we told her we'd stage a customer's strike if she didn't give you time off to win the Open. This remark penetrates Tin Cup's concentration.   He turn with a smile to the regulars. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You perverts did that for me? JOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe in you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you get past the local qualifier, we gonna sponsor you. Tin Cup looks at the beaming faces of the regulars and smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, boys -- a man couldn't have better friends. Now move the hell back and shut the fuck up. You're messing up my concentration. And with big smiles, they move each other back so as not to mess up Tin Cup's concentration. And he pulls out another ball, mutters dollar bills, and hits another perfect shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's gone home except Tin Cup, who keeps drilling beautiful shots into the Texas night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car is parked unnoticed. A figure sits alone, watching Tin Cup from a distance. Molly.

dialogues.speaker: SOLITARY FIGURE OF TIN CUP
dialogues.text: With his elegant swing,   as graceful as he is crude, a Z ritual. Finally, weary    at last, Tin Cup tosses his clu in his bag and drags it   toward his ever-present Winnebago, which we see   him enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops his clubs on the couch. The place is a wreck, and he collapses in a chair, CRACKING a CAN of cheap BEER. A KNOCK at the door.   He's startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debt collection? Process server?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ex-flame? Jesus, I'm clean. (disguises his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it? The door opens -- Molly enters. He's surprised but well- settled into his bath of cynicism. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you've got a beautiful swing -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And big, beautiful green eyes -- I'm a beautiful guy. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here to apologize. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I counseled you, you did exactly what I said, and I just... poured cold water over your effort. (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get it. I'm a terrible shrink, probably... I should've never got out of real estate -- actually I should never have left Ohio for that cowboy in Armarillo -- have you ever been to Amarillo? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cowboy? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as romantic when you're actually with one -- a wrangler, y'know -- so of course the oil man in Dallas looked great after that -- I don't know what I was thinking... That's when I went to the gulf and ended up in, well, trailer sales and then all those condos in Corpus Christi -- the bottom fell outta the market and I needed a new gig -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new gig? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therapy.    I took all the classes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm licensed, y'know. (suddenly dejected)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God... (reaching into her purse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I smoke? (lights up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'm flattered you asked me out. I can't accept because I am involved with David and I haven't seen any evidence that he treats old people, kids or dogs badly. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a little carried away, I guess. I shoulda just layed up, made my par, and moved on. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I want to propose something -- as long as you understand this is professional -- we're not going out together -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tee it up. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can help you with the mental aspects of the game. You've got Romeo to be your swing doctor, I can be your head doctor. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said you were a lousy shrink? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah... I'll improve. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no money to pay for you. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll trade my services for golf lessons and help you through the qualifying. If you get into the Open, well, you're on your own. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be with David. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Silence.   A deal.   It's the best they can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local qualifier. The First Tee of the Local Open Qualifier. And the voice of the starter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the next group... Roy McAvoy, Salome, Texas... who will be playing with... The regulars applaud and whistle and shout way too many "You the man's!" as Tin Cup steps onto the first tee, followed by his Sancho Panza, Romeo. Tin Cup is feeling on top of the world, at his cocky best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya feelin', boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm feelin' like par's a bad score, podnuh -- fifty-eight's within the realm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, the doctor lady's here --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: standing not far from the regulars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell ya? She's gonna be your guru partner. You handle my swing mechanics and she handles my brain mechanics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long as you keep your dick out of it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me an' the 'big guy' have an understanding. He's gonna lie low till I get in the Open -- then... then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Dog'll eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Dog'll hunt, that's for sure... Tin Cup steps up to the tee, a couple quick limber

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: swings, and he tees it up.   As he does, Romeo slips over to Molly. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Looks like we partners, Dr. Molly
MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to help him keep his head on straight -- ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can, you be the first. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does have the occasional tendency towards self-destruction it seems. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't occasional and it ain't no tendency -- it's a fact of life that he gonna blow sky high, it's just a matter of when and how fast can the pieces be put back together. (beat) Behind that twinkle in his eyes is nitroglycerin. Tin Cup waves and motions to his team. TIN CUP
