dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet in the gallery! A man's trying to do his job. And Tin Cup uncoils a mighty drive with an elegant stroke, fully confident and smooth. The gallery applauds. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (generally announcing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got my 'A' game with me today, folks... you're in for a real treat! Molly leans to Romeo just before they all head down the fairway and confides -- MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find him mildly attractive when he's obnoxious and arrogant like this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. 'Cause it's his best side... And they head down the fairway, a scruffy little gallery on a so-so course. With a lot at stake...

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP'S FRONT NINE
dialogues.text: He hits a perfect wedge -- and says to himself, Romeo, Molly, the gallery, the universe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... 49   He nails a two iron straight as a string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nutted it... 50   He rifles another drive into the stratosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Hogan?   Who's he? 51   Putt after putt drains into the jar. 52   CLOSE ON the SCOREBOARD -- The red numbers (under pa are going up quickly as every shot he hits is dead, solid perfect. Minus one, two, four, five, seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's in a zone, talking to himself, full of himself, in a fabulous, indomitable state of mind. Molly and Romeo keep looking at each other and shrugging, Tin Cup's on a roll and needs no help. So far... A couple of the regulars shout out encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the man, Tin Cup! You the man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bugging you, boss -- I can shut 'em up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way I'm swinging today,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nothing bugs me -- except insufficient applause. (surveying the fairway)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the lumber. But Romeo is handing him a two iron. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think two iron's safer. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I want the Big Dog. Romeo looks warily down the fairway of a tight dogleg left par five. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight par five, out of bounds left... you don't want to hit driver. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going left of those trees. I'm going over those trees... with a little draw. That way I get home in two. That way I'm putting for eagle. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need eagle to qualify! You need to get used to playing smart -- no mistakes wins the Open. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qualify? I want the course record! Now gimme the lumber! Tin Cup reaches for the driver.   Romeo shifts the golf bag beyond Tin Cup's reach. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You not going to listen to me? You don't care I'm trying to help? You think I'm full of shit? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna get penalized for slow play if you don't give me that fucking driver. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a head case, boss, always were, always will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's ask the head doctor. Dr. Griswold? (to Molly) Dr. Griswold, should I hit the Big Dog or the two? Suddenly an OFFICIAL steps forward. P.G.A. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soliciting shot selection advice is a two-stroke penalty. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust your feelings, Roy. TIN CUP (to Romeo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!   Gimme the driver and shut up. Romeo pulls out the driver and he snaps it in half over his knee. He tosses the two halves on the ground near Tin Cup. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Go ahead.    Hit the driver. Tin Cup looks at the two halves of his driver, curbing his anger, not giving Romeo the satisfaction of a reaction. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed my mind. Gimme the three wood. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't clear the dogleg with a three wood. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna bet? Romeo pulls out the three wood, snaps it     over his kne and tosses the halves on the ground next     to the drive halves. Tin Cup turns with amusement to      his playing partners, lest they think management has     lost the upp hand with labor. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I'm going with the safe shot, boys. Tin Cup reaches for the two iron, studies it a moment, frowns, and then: He snaps it over his knee. He dumps these halves on the ground with the halves of the driver and three wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo stares, aghast.   Tin Cup merely shrugs. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I fan that two iron. Better gimme the three. Romeo warily hands Tin Cup the three iron.    Tin Cup loo at it, frowns, then: He snaps it over his knee and tosses it on the ground. Molly leans over to the regulars. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this normal behavior for him? EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word 'normal' and him don't collide in the same sentence too often. She watches in amazement as -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I catch that three a little thin... He drops the three iron halves with the other halves, and steps past Romeo and sequentially yanks all but the seven iron from his bag. He snaps them over his knee, one by one, citing the crimes of each club with mounting absurdity and ire. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've hooked my four iron... (snap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and hit flyers with the five... (snap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and shanked the six... (snap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and skulled the eight... (snap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and fatted the nine... (snap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and chili-dipped the wedge... (snap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and bladed the sand wedge... (snap; then pauses to reflect contemptuously on his putter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and then there's Mister Three-putt... He snaps the putter in half and dumps it in the pile of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: broken clubs at his feet. Then, he reaches for the last club in his bag, the seven iron. The regulars hold their breath, thinking this is the end of Tin Cup's Open bid. But... Tin Cup smiles and caresses the seven iron affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the seven iron, I never miss the seven iron. It's the only truly safe club in my bag. He moves to the tee, drops a ball, and hits it down the middle with the seven iron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You happy, Romeo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, boss, I'm tired... my life's too short to spend it watching you fall apart. I done it too many times. Romeo turns and starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? You're quitting? First sign of adversity, you're quitting? (as Romeo continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone want to bet me I can't par in with a seven iron? (to Molly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc? Take the bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy -- just shut up and hit the ball.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's magic with a seven iron.   He drives with a seven iron. 55   He chips with a seven iron. 56   He blasts out of sand with an open-bladed seven iron

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup drains a ten foot putt -- also with the seven iron, and left-handed to boot. He's past the local qualifier. The regulars erupt in cheers.   You'd have thought he won the Masters. And Tin Cup shrugs to the tiny gallery, with insouciance and cockiness, and pronounces --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An easy game, this golf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup holds court surrounded by his regulars and much of the gallery. He's a local hero -- but Molly's not impressed. A WAITRESS delivers a tray of long neck beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the man, Tin Cup! A toast is raised to their king, and Tin Cup eats it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, boys, what'ya think was my best shot -- the seven iron on twelve, the seven iron on fourteen, or maybe it was the bunker shot on eighteen which, to my recollection was a -- seven iron? Much laughter.   This is the Tin Cup they love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You definitely the man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd I do, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You failed miserably.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: What?! I parred the back nine with a seven iron, I qualified for the regionals, I --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Your job is not just to qualify for the Open, it's to prepare for the Open. My job is to help you prepare.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: You said to 'trust my feelings'!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I didn't know you felt like breaking all the clubs in your bag.

dialogues.speaker: CLINT
dialogues.text: He didn't break the seven!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: He smoked that seven, brother --

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: From what I understand, the U.S. Open is the most difficult golf tournament in the world played under the most difficult circumstances with the greatest players -- winning it means controlling yourself, managing your emotions, staying cool, not getting in a pissing contest with your caddie who, incidentally, quit.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: He always quits, he always comes back.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Nonetheless, from the mental aspect -- which is my domain -- you have regressed and are fumbling somewhere between delusion and denial.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: 'Regression, delusion, denial'? You gotta use all this psychological language?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'm a psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup turns to the regulars for support. VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a bad day, Roy? Everyone turns to see David Simms enter the conversation. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, honey... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shot 65 -- parred the backside with a seven iron. SIMMS (intrigued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the question -- why? Silence. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause he broke all his other clubs. EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snapped 'em in two -- even the putter. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Roy, I'm on your side here. We go way back... I hope you get into the Open, but if you don't play under control, you'll get slaughtered. Good players shoot 82 in the Open. You can't always go for it. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear to God, Doc, this guy is not who you think. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a well-known fact that if a camera's not on him, he treats old people and children like dirt. EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And dogs. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't forget the dogs. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should go, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so... Tin Cup's worst characteristics flare up, he won't let go. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever shoot par with a seven iron? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never occurred to me to try. (to Molly) C'mon, let's go. The car's over here.... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet you a thousand dollars against my car that I can beat you in any game -- any game, you name it -- with a seven iron. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a coward? You gonna lay up the way you did at the Masters last year? REGULARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taunting, like children)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chickie, chickie, chickie... Simms is a little drawn in, not so much by the challenge as the desire to shut up Tin Cup. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any game, I name it? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, David -- SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to teach him a lesson. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do men insist on measuring their dicks? Tin Cup takes her literally and rises, starting to unbuckle his belt. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, awright! Let's measure,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: right now! MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God sakes, I wasn't being literal! (beat) David, let's go. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, trust me on this one. Call it part of his mental preparation for the Open, where the rough is deep, the greens are slick, and the nerves are shattered. (to Tin Cup) I'll take the bet. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, jeez... The Regulars cheer -- this is what they live for. Simms hands a roll of cash to Molly. Tin Cup hands her his car keys. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright!   What's the game? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One swing each. Who can hit the longest seven iron -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lock! I hit the seven like John Daly hits a three! The Regulars whoop it up. Their man's a cinch. Tin Cup pulls a ball from his pocket, drops it right on the ground in the middle of the patio. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From right here, okay? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine with me. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are really being childish -- SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, leave this one to me. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Griswold, I know what I'm doing. Tin Cup takes a couple of swings to limber up, aiming out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: onto an open area of the course.   Serious, intent, the look of eagles... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Dollar bills... He takes a full back-swing, opens beautifully, and launches a seven iron like a rocket out toward some driving range markers... to "oohs" and "ahhs" from his faithful. The ball lands at a 170 yard marker and bounces further. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them signs are at least thirty yards farther -- that ball musta gone 220... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ball's about 2-2-7... toed it a bit... but it'll do... REGULARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly 230 with a seven!    Pureed it, baby, he pureed it! Tin Cup hands Simms the seven iron. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a minute to limber up, fine with me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need to. Simms is still in a sport jacket, slacks, no golf shoes. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your jacket off? SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm fine. Simms drops a ball about where Tin Cup's sat.   He stands above the ball and addresses it. TIN CUP (cockily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna need to muscle up, big guy -- give it the old steroid jerk... Simms is cool as ice. He smiles, then moves around to the other side of the ball, suddenly facing away from the course. This baffles everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you doin'?    Wha's this? And David Simms hits an effortless seven iron out toward the desert, onto the lonely highway... 59   ... and the ball bounces and bounces and bounces, fo About three miles, forever. It's probably still going...

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: The hustler's been hustled.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: She shrugs and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly drives away in Simms' car -- followed by Simms in Tin Cup's Cadillac convertible. Simms waves. Tin Cup and the Regulars stand alone. Weakly, lamely, a couple of the Regulars speak. Without conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the man, Roy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You definitely the man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nearly nude dancer named SAMMANTHA on stage to a big Saturday night crowd. Tin Cup's in the front row, sitting with Doreen and a beer. Disconsolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring out those bills, boys, if ya wanta see a little more of Sammantha! Guys pull out singles and larger bills around the runway, placing them on the railing for the gyrating stripper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tin Cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup tosses some money onstage with a lackluster wave, he's depressed -- or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey... DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you qualified for the Regionals -- why you so down? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I broke my clubs -- don't ask why, my caddie's pissed off at me, I lost my wheels in a sucker bet, and my shrink thinks I'm a fool -- 'cause I probably am... DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're seeing a therapist?! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what's wrong with that? DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only way you'd ever go into therapy was if the shrink was a doll and you were trying to get her into the rack -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so shallow. The Good Doctor and I are dealing with my regression and denial -- DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Tin Cup, what a crock.    You got a hard-on. A GUY from the next table leans over, interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You `Tin Cup'?     Won the Local with a seven iron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McAvoy?   The Tin Cup McAvoy? DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one -- thank God... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   You looking for a game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'd sure like to show you my grip... Doreen can't keep his attention. Neither can Sammantha, who writhes only a few feet away. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been seeing this `Good Doctor'? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Dor', the man's having trouble with his grip -- The Guy slides over to Tin Cup, quickly joined by his buddies. GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I used to play a real weak grip. But you look at Couples, he's got a left hand way over here... Tin Cup glances at the guy's grip. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, grip it like this, so you're holding on with the last two fingers of your left hand. The Guy nudges the COWBOY next to him. GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that? Tin Cup McAvoy says you grip a golf club like this, with these two fingers. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy? (off no response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy?   Tin Cup? Hello? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grip and address are about 90 percent of the golf swing, so pay attention here... COWBOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're done with him, can I ask you about my club position at address? Sammantha can't keep their attention, either, even though she's down to a G-string, inches away. At the height of the MUSIC, she stops dancing and looks down at Doreen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I doing something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey, you ain't -- but a healthy woman's only got two choices in this world of ours... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either fall in love with another woman -- or take up golf. And Doreen heads to the dressing room, disgusted, but not at all surprised. She knows Tin Cup -- she knows men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Now the stronger right-hand grip can help ya draw the ball, which I plan to do at the Regionals next week in Tulsa... just shift the hand over a little bit... blah, blah, blah... ... And naked women dance before them, unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WINNEBAGO CHUGS along in the middle of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup drives, as most of the Regulars lounge -- all are there including Turk (the bouncer). But Romeo is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get through the next 36 holes and we in the Open!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the yips and I ain't even teeing it up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to worry about, boys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you ain't got Romeo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need him till the Open -- he'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't got the doctor lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, I got her. Right here. He holds up a tape cassette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't travel to Arizona for the Regionals -- she's got a busy practice, y'know... so she made me this tape to play while I'm out there... keep me calm, cool, and collected...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little James Taylor, little George Jones, little Kahlil Gibran, little this, little that... and a lotta the voice of the smartest chick I ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good doctor herself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we hear it or is it personal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when is therapy personal, eh? He punches into his deck and the Winnebago is filled with the sounds of MOLLY'S TAPE, beginning with George Jones... ... and the voice of GEORGE JONES takes us into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Regional Qualifier -- 36-hole tournament pitting all the local winners. This is a much bigger deal than the local tournament -- more commercial, bigger crowds, tougher.

dialogues.speaker: REGIONALS
dialogues.text: Accompanied by MOLLY'S VOICE and the MUSIC of JONES, TAYLOR, OTHERS.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: He puts the Walkman headset over his ears on the first tee. We hear what he hears, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... `Private victories precede public victories. You cannot harvest a crop before you plant it...' Kaboom!   He launches a tee shot down the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... `How you view the problem, is the problem...' 66   TIN CUP chips into the cup. 67   TIN CUP drains putt after putt with confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... `Follow your bliss...' 68   TIN CUP takes a club from Earl who's huffing and puffing a little too hard for a caddie, and -- Tin Cup crisps a three iron over water to a tight green. Tin Cup is carrying his own bag now -- Earl is several paces behind, dragging his body slowly, exhausted. 69   CLOSE ON SCOREBOARD -- Even par, even, even, one under...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... `Say not that I have found the truth but that I have found a truth...' 70   CLOSE ON TIN CUP -- Still in a zone, confident, relaxed, hitting lots of good shots. But the score is close, the competition tougher. He's near the top, but not first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71   TIN CUP lips out a fifteen-foot putt -- heartbreak. He starts to lose it, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...`You can't have the fruits without the roots...' And Tin Cup just smiles and taps in. 72   SCOREBOARD tells us we're down to the 36th, final ho

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Whattya think, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think three under will qualify. You need birdie. I could shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little more confidence there, Earl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish Romeo was here. I ain't cut out to do this. I'm a spectator by nature. An observer. I'm a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and hand me the Big Dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it. Tin Cup takes the driver and uncoils a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Force is with me, pods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74   TIN CUP hits a wedge approach -- the ball lands inch from the hole. The crowd gasps... but -- The backspin grabs it and the ball spins back and back and back, ten, twenty, thirty feet before coming to a rest. The men head solemnly to the final green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup surveys the thirty-foot snake of a putt.   Earl's of absolutely no use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need this one big time, Earl, whattya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsurely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks straight to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight?! Thing's a roller coaster breaks four ways and dies at the hole -- you're blind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I am blind... 20-60 in one eye -- and that's the good eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a blind caddie... just hold the stick, Earl -- and be sure to pull it out... Tin Cup studies the hell out of this putt. If it goes in, he's in the Open. He misses, back to Salome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... when the going gets tough, the, the, the, whirrrrrrrrrrr, the, the... Tin Cup shakes the Walkman and pounds his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc?  Doc? (panicky)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, Earl -- the tape's jammed! She's abandoning me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... I'm flying solo now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta make this putt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously. Tin Cup stares endlessly at the long putt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... just pick the line, feel the speed -- bad timing, doc, Jesus... He steps up to the putt, still talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a million others you made in your life, Roy. Just see it going in. Just feel it... right in the back of the jar... just pull the goddamn trigger, you pussy... 76   He strokes the putt -- It starts right, curls back left, straightens out, over the ridge, back again, endlessly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull the stick, Earl, pull it! Earl's having trouble with the flagstick, shaking it, panicking, and finally -- he snaps it free, but... The ball stops dead on the lip of the cup. Tin Cup contorts in anguished body-English, then falls to his back like a shot animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choking dogs die! And the BALL falls into the cup with a CLICK -- and a ROAR. Tin Cup takes a peek at the cup.   The ball stays in the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Winnebago returns home, a travelling party of beer, boisterousness, and celebration. We hear them all, led by Turk the bouncer and his guitar, singing "The Double bogey Blues"... all the way back to Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup arrives, fresh from the qualifier.   Romeo is shafting glubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romes!  You've come back! (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda been there, Romes, I drained a 30-foot snake to qualify! (off no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl gave me a straight read -- the thing broke half a dozen times -- missed ya, pods! Romeo gives him the silent treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, don't talk to me -- but you're still my guy... (losing patience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little late to be pissed off! We're in the Open! You and me! Still nothing from Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, be that way -- (switches course)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- say... has Molly been around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you had the hots for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? Garbo speaks? Of course I have the hots for her and I'm doing a damn good job of keeping things platonic and professional till I kick Simms' ass and show her I ain't who she thinks I am because, in fact, I am who she thinks I am but if I win the Open I won't be. Romeo stares back at that curious logic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think her nor me nor the God of Golf his self can keep you from blowing up in the Open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made it this far! I just got to hold it together for 72 more

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: holes! ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lotta triple bogeys out there waiting to grab your ass. TIN CUP (cheerily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're complaining again! Romeo's back! Whining, bitching, pissed off -- you're my man! Silence.   Some chagrin. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't fall in love with Earl to be your caddie? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a wheezing heart attack waiting to happen -- cost me three strokes a side... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carried my bag the last four holes. I love ol' Earl but I need you. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't love me? TIN CUP (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too, God damn it! ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as Earl? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! Yes, yes, as much as Earl -- (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than Earl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I special? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can remove the sexual connotations and overlay a golf theme, Romeo -- I am your Juliet. Romeo ponders it all. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muy bien, Julietta. In that case -- I am your caddy once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Podnuh. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright... now that we got that bullshit outta the way, I'm gonna hit me some balls and start oilin' that sweet swing o' mine for the big boys... Romeo sits back in the shade, still washing the thousands of golf balls in the rack, watching as -- 79   Tin Cup drops a bucket of balls on the hardscrabble ground, pulls out a club and limbers up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody heard from Molly, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it bad, don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' about that chick... Tin Cup addresses the ball and takes a swing.    Everythi looks normal in his swing, but... Thwock! -- the BALL squirls off to the side and RATTLES against a fence. Ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm... little chili dipper there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure to do that in the Open. Unfazed, Tin Cup steps up to hit again, but... once more -- Thwock! -- Another horrible-looking squib to the right. Romeo stops washing balls and notices, watching Tin Cup. Thwock, thwock! -- Something's terribly wrong.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Concern crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't no chili dipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, boss, you got the 'S' word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shanks are like a virus -- they just show up. Nobody can figure 'em out. Thwock, thwock, thwock! -- Three more chili dippers.   Ou man definitely has the shanks. And he's panicking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romes!   Something's terribly wrong.   What's your guess?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said it was a virus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman can have the same effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep swinging...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thwock, thwock, thwock! -- Night has fallen and he still has the shanks. The regulars have gathered and are huddled, murmuring. The word has spread like wildfire -- Tin Cup has the shanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought it would happen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shanks is for us mortals, not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for the great ones... JOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esta muy feo... muy, muy feo... (It is very ugly, very, very ugly...) Tin Cup angrily throws his club out into the night and turns to the regulars. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know why they named this game 'golf'? 'Cause the words 'fuck' and 'shit' were already taken! A CAR HORN HONKS -- All heads turn to see:

dialogues.speaker: PINK CORVETTE
dialogues.text: pulls in -- Doreen gets out, carrying a big package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, fellas! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Everybody like to watch a train wreck?! Doreen approaches the regulars, and we notice for the first time that there are a number of bags and packages with the boys. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in one of his pleasant moods, I see -- ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the shanks. We got the makings of a Greek tragedy here. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to Tin Cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit whining and get over here. We've got something for you. Tin Cup drags his sorry ass to the group. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless it's a 'swing thought,' I'm not interested... DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring his attitude)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here to sponsor you in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open. Me an' the boys have pooled our resources and come up with some cash so you can look and feel as spiffy as all them big-name pros. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I got the shanks -- DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you obviously still have a hard-on for the doctor chick -- your face is all screwed up and tight like you haven't been laid in awhile -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it really that obvious? DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a good look for you. Roy, your heart is not the only organ you wear on your sleeve. There's a certain, vulgar appeal to your transparency. Tin Cup shrugs.   She always has him outflanked. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Tin Cup, we're trying to make you a presentation -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, awright... She unwraps a tour golf bag -- Big gold and red lettering advertises "The Golden Tassel." Pastie tassels hang from all over the bag. Doreen sets it down proudly. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the Golden Tassel to sponsor you at the Open. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to pack that around? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm carrying the bag. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth four hundred dollars endorsement money to you -- Earl steps forward with a golf shirt bedecked with sewn on patches and logos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Dewey got you First State Banking of Salome, and Clint got you Short-Haul Trucking and I got you Brink and Brown sanitation -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm being sponsored by a sewage disposal system? EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call it human resources management, Roy, please... Jose steps forward with a golf cap, also emblazoned. JOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got Wally's Smokehouse for ya -- kind of a nice sign... DEWEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And since I couldn't get the post office to come aboard, me and my girl friend Muriel's gonna buy a fan club patch you can put anywhere you want. Doreen and the regulars look at Tin Cup proudly. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to wear this shit? JOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shit is us, man.   You can't win without us. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the pride of Salome! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I won't even make the cut! DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your confidence? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's shanking his love life so he's shanking the golf ball. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be true love. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a goner. Tin Cup surveys all the bizarre sponsorship loot, and starts loosening up. These are his people, after all,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and they're behind him all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, everybody, this is great. I'm sorry I'm acting so pathetic but my swing's never abandoned me before. I just need a little time to work it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you want --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him some room, boys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to anyone who'll listen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's my grip... maybe I'm opening up too soon... too late... coming over the top... no, dropping underneath... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sweet Jesus, why have you abandoned me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the regulars)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to talk to God.   It's time for us to go. Doreen and the regulars quietly slip away to leave Tin Cup with his newly sponsored gifts and, more importantly, his newly lost grip, swing, and confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to stay, boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it. And Romeo herds the rest of them out to their cars in the lot. And as they drive away, Tin Cup sits down, his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Winnebago sits forlornly in the parking lot next to the range which has never looked lonelier. Tin Cup's Caddy convertible pulls up to the Winnebago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Roy isn't driving -- Molly is.    She gets out, goes the door. She knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy?   Anybody home? There's no answer so she tries the door, and walks in on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup stands there caught, like a deer in the headlights, like a man caught cross dressing, a private confession made public -- he can't run and he can't hide... Roy "Tin Cup" McAvoy is wearing every gimmick that Molly first arrived with -- plus many more. He wears a pendulum cap, his arms are strapped together, a curious triangular coat hanger type contraption connects his elbows, there's a neck brace, an ankle anchor, an arrow attachment to his left hand, a bucket for right foot, he swings a collapsible club... and a BEGINNERS GOLF VIDEO PROJECTS loudly from his VCR, so loudly that he never heard her knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aarghh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Griswold... A moment of pathetic silence, then: Molly starts laughing -- He is destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The therapist laughs at her patient? Is that how it works? A man is laid bare before God and he's the butt of the cosmic joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of this shit might actually

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: work, y'know... I mean I think there's something to this hat with the pendulum golf ball thing... may be on to something here... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Roy, Jesus... Quoting yourself, 'It is the paraphernalia for lost and desperate souls.' Tin Cup lets down. The wind goes out of his sails and he loses his defensiveness. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, God damn... a lost and desperate soul stands before you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume I have the confidentiality of doctor-client privilege in regards to this outfit? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you do. What happened? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the shanks. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you taking penicillin? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be treated! It's much worse than whatever you thought it was. (beat) There's a glitch in my swing. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's in Romeo's department? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks it's your department -- says it's a head thing. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. I just came over to congratulate you on the regionals and return your car -- David says he doesn't want it, just wanted to make a point with you -- (beat) But I suppose we could have a therapy session right here and now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want therapy. I want you. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy...   I gotta get some air -- TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me -- (considering what that means)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not right at the moment -- but listen to me. You're with the wrong guy. I'm the right guy. Everyone tells me my face is all screwed up tight as a drum 'cause I've been crazy about you from the day you showed up wearing this stupid stuff and the whole damn thing has both inspired me to get here on the verge of greatness yet it's also caused me to get the shanks which could humiliate me in front of a zillion people. (beat) Such is life. So dump that phony bastard and come to the Open in my corner -- you can delay your romantic urges, which I know are lurking in there among the excess of brain cells you possess -- until the appropriate time... (beat) Tell me you're not at least moderately attracted to me. Tin Cup stands there with the ball still dangling from his hat, the leather straps, the bucket, the arrows -- for the moment he's forgotten how stupid he looks. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have moments. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me which ones are my moments and I'll try to duplicate them. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a moment. You look great. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?! MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utterly exposed, completely vulnerable, the inner child trying to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My inner child needs spanking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always liked that part about saddling up, the smell of leather

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's have a drink. Call it therapy. Charge me 75 an hour. Little Cuervo, little Freud... She's thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw... I gotta go. (turns to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't have a car, I need a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Molly in his convertible.   He works on her without pushing too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a spot along the river's great to watch the sunset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Not tonight' means maybe some other night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consciously you didn't mean it like that -- but how about unconsciously, you're the expert, did you mean it unconsciously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unconsciously, Roy, I don't have a clue what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel we're making progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do too. But I have no idea what it's progress towards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy pulls up in front of her office at the new mall. She gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck in the Open, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your money on me, Doc, the odds are fabulous and God knows I'm overdue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives away, and we stay:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Watching Tin Cup careen away in his Caddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intrepid Winnebago on the way to the Open.    Romeo drives -- Tin Cup stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to relax, boss --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' to the U.S. Open with the shanks. Gonna be chili dipping my way around the course on worldwide television... sure, relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get rid of them shanks for ya. No hay problema.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly and I are circling each other... I can feel it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She the enemy, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well she wakin' up with the enemy -- same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Romes -- the absolute truth -- you think I can go 72 holes without falling apart. Romeo keeps driving, pretends not to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me! I don't want no bullshit... do you think I can do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, boss, I just don't know. And Tin Cup puts on his Walkman, and stares out the window endlessly at a thousand miles of passing scenery, to the MUSIC of GEORGE JONES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WINNEBAGO RUMBLES out of the country heading east, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Winnebago heads out of the high plains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Winnebago passes through a "tunnel" of tall, old pines into a cathedral environment of old money and old golf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo and Tin Cup stare out into the trees, the lushness -- a couple of wide-eyed kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet this is the first Winnebago they ever saw here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... and the first Mexican... The Winnebago pulls up to a guard gate -- A SECURITY GUARD comes to the window. A banner hangs above the entrance a few paces past the security gate, proclaiming: "Old Pines -- U.S. Open Championship." SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Como esta, amigo. I have with me one of the legendary ball strikers in the history of golf -- The Security Guard strains to see in. SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? Mr. Crenshaw? That you? Mr. Price, Mr. Norman? No? Tin Cup leans across Romeo to introduce himself. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy 'Tin Cup' McAvoy. Representing the great American Southwest. The Guard backs off quickly, turns to his SECOND. SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have a... McCormack... on the list. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McAvoy -- Roy McAvoy -- he's a legend! SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got over 150 legends in this tournament. Sorry. Romeo starts cursing in Spanish.   The Guard is unphased. SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the police. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police? The police quickly appear to take over the situation. Tin Cup leaps out of the Winnebago to argue his point. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a mistake here, fellas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COP grabs Tin Cup and Roy is ready to fight.   It's getting ugly real fast. COP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll throw your ass in jail right now, pal -- there's a lotta lunatics here and we don't take chances... At that moment David Simms pulls in, driving a con- vertible sponsor's car. He sees the scuffle, gets out. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem here? SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This clown says he's in the Open... Simms spots Tin Cup -- a delicious moment for him. Tin Cup wants to hide but he just gamely covers his face. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, David... nice sweater. SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not on the list. Simms takes the clipboard with the list. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Roy... welcome to the big leagues... (checks the list) Here ya go, Charlie, his name's right here. (to Tin Cup) They spelled your name wrong -- easy mistake with a total unknown. SECURITY GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cop) Let him in. Simms smiles at Tin Cup, the easy smile of a man on top. Tin Cup doesn't respond, just asks the Guard: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way to the practice range? As Tin Cup tries to regain some dignity, and climbs back into the Winnebago --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he was a 'legend'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh he is... he's a very big name at a driving range in Salome, Texas... They all have a good laugh, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of the big names are there.   Romeo is like a kid at the ballpark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Right there! Fred Couples... and Ray Floyd! Romeo notices that Tin Cup is staring at the pile of practice balls lying there on the tee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these balls. Brand new Titleists. Lookit 'em, every one a brand new Titleist. (lowers his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneak a few in the bag when you get a chance. We swipe enough free shit we might even pay for this fiasco. Tin Cup limbers up, trying not to be in awe of the real legends who line the practice range, hitting beautiful shot after beautiful shot with graceful ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it would be inappropriate to ask Ray Floyd for an autograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a dead giveaway, Romes... but if I still got the shanks we're gonna be found out real fast... Tin Cup nudges a ball from the pile into address position. Romeo hands him a different club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the seven iron. You never miss the seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thought, Pods... Tin Cup waggles, shakes, limbers, addresses... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... And he swings. THWOCK! A hideous shank squirrels across line, almost hitting a group of U.S. Open officials. Heads turn. TIN CUP (to anyone who'll listen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who hit that shot? Anybody see? He addresses another one.   And swings. THWOCK!   A disaster.   He crumbles. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little thin, Boss. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little fucking thin?! I still got the shanks! Everybody's watching! Christ, Simms is here... Simms has arrived and is watching Tin Cup with delight as he loosens up. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should work on putting. Ya can't shank a putt. Tin Cup pretends to limber a little more before daring to strike another ball. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're the Mexican Mac O'Grady, Romes, you gotta figure out why I'm still shanking the ball. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem? I'm catching it on the hosel, right? Moving my head? I'm laying off it, I'm pronating, I'm supinating, I'm clearing too early, I'm clearing too late, I'm off plane, I ain't dropping in -- oh, God, my swing feels like an unfolding lawn chair. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a virus in your brain.   I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: got to kill the brain to kill the virus. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.   Kill me now! ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put all your change in your right pocket. Tin Cup follows orders, not questioning the logic. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Now tie your left shoelace in a double knot. Again, Tin Cup dutifully follows orders. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esta bueno. Now, turn your hat around backwards and put a blue tee behind your right ear... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look like a fool. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you think you look like hitting those squirrelly chili peppers up Freddy Couples' ass, eh? Do what I say or I quit. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect... now hit a seven iron into that tree over there. You're ready. Tin Cup hits a perfect seven iron into the trees. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd I do that? ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't thinking about shanking, you ain't thinking about the doctor lady, you ain't thinking period. You just lookin' like a fool and hittin' it pure -- your natural state. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Your brain was getting in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's rarely been a problem. What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I should recommend you go work on your short game but I think it's better if you go get drunk instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You always play better when you're wasted. Tin Cups stares at the swami, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again to GEORGE JONES on the CASSETTE PLAYER, Tin Cup is doing a slow dance with his driver. Romeo sits on the couch, stone cold sober, pouring drink after drink for Tin Cup, who's thoroughly plastered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three in the morning, Romes, what time I tee off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven-o-five... first group off... Keep drinking, keep dancing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's four hours from now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're drinking till five... c'mon, c'mon, have another -- (a tough coach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get you in shape --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup tosses down yet another drink, and staggers around the room with his driver until, finally, he collapses in a heap on the floor. Romeo looks down at him coolly, like horse trainer Wayne Lukas sizing up his Derby entry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like the sight of a finely-tuned athlete on the verge of greatness... Romeo tosses a blanket over Tin Cup lying on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two figures hurry across the lawn to the first tee.    Ou intrepid Don Quixote and Sancho Panza.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: The first tee -- the early morning air is heavy and still. The course is quiet and wet with dew. The gallery is sparse. The silence is broken by the starter's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the honor in the 7:08 pairing, from Salome, Texas, Mr. Roy McAvoy. A half-dozen people clap, and -- Tin Cup and Romeo stagger to the tee, barely making it on time. Tin Cup is massively hung-over and unshaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time for a bucket, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost missed the starting time trying to get you off the floor, boss. You don't handle the hooch like you used to... Tin Cup tries to get warm quickly, taking a few hurried practice swings. The early tee times are strictly for the longest of long shots, and almost nobody is around. Tin Cup's hand shakes as he closes the Velcro flap on his glove. He's wearing the hat and shirt with the sew-on patches, as he stares down the first fairway. Romeo hands him a driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen this hole on TV. Hit the big dog down the chute --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've learned my lesson. Gonna play it safe, smart, conservative. Fairways and greens. Hand me the two iron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought of the day is -- `be humble.' And Tin Cup launches a two iron down the first fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scorer posts an eighty-three next to Tin Cup's name. Tin Cup stares, shell-shocked, as his score is posted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty-three.    Well, you humble now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven bogeys and seven pars. I didn't make a three. I didn't make one goddam three all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't trying to make threes. You were trying to avoid making thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hungover!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that was a coaching error on my part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, amigo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Simms is interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the television)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the last person who expected me to come out of the blocks with a sixty-seven and lead the Open... It's been a long time since I played this game with the fire and determination you need to win...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Anti-Christ shoots 67, you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ol' Anti-Christ got a hot putter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on television)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you see, this game is all about integrity and tradition and honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? It's about cheating and racism and bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, boss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live coverage of the Simms interview. Molly is among a small crowd gathered to watch. He doesn't seem to know that she's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (live on mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tomorrow I'll just go out there and try to make some good swings and, Lord willing, maybe I can put up another good number. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, David Simms, a brilliant opening round 67 to take the lead. Simms walks away, now off-camera.   FANS call out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!   David!     Over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go. Simms cuts down behind the tent toward the clubhouse, away from the galleries. The marshals open a rope allowing him to avoid the crowds, but -- An ELDERLY COUPLE with a young child are there.   The lad has a tiny dog in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Simms! (off no response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you sign an autograph for our grandson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you see I'm busy?! I'm working! This is my office! Do I come to your office and ask you for an autograph?! Jesus... He practically stiff-arms them as he passes, heading up to the clubhouse. They stand there in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck these people think they are... CAMERA PANS OVER TO the edge of the tent. Molly, trying to get to David, has seen the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: She speaks to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old people, children, and dogs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms enters to numerous congratulations from officials, caddies, other PLAYERS. Instantly, in public, he feigns humility with convincing flair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva round, Dave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got lucky out there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great start, Simmsy... Simms stops when he sees Tin Cup and Romeo drowning their sorrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tin Cup -- heard you put a monster number up there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda been worse... A small bar crowd is enjoying Simms' taunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I played in the Pro-Am with some asshole movie star shot 82 here once... how did a great ball- striker like you, a `legend,' manage to shoot an 83?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed a four foot putt on the eighteen for an 82, that's how...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't like playing some muni track in Brownsville, is it? A voice interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does, `integrity, tradition, and honor' include kicking a man when he's down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mol', this is just guy stuff, bar talk, part of the game -- no offense, right, Cup? No answer.    Tin Cup's about as low as one can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man still has a lot of good golf shots in his system --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to hide)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, it's okay, go away... I don't need any attention right

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: now... SOME GUY AT THE BAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tin Cup) You the guy shot 83?! MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, I'll bet you a hundred dollars right now that Roy here can hit a ball -- (looks around) -- from right here to... through that door to the patio... She points to a double door, forty feet away across, the bar, about an 8 x 8 foot opening. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, please... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bartender) And give me a vodka tonic with a twist -- SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, really, this isn't... dignified... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy? TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta go back to Texas... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the river, the piranha, the immortality? All that bullshit? You gonna drag your ass home with an 83? (looks around) In fact, two hundred says he can hit it through that door, over the patio, into the river, and make that pelican fly off that post. Everyone strains to look --

dialogues.speaker: ABOUT 170 YARDS AWAY
dialogues.text: A pelican sits on a piling in the river.   Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous... But Romeo's sizing it up. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that shot, Pods, hood the seven, turn it over, start it low, right to left... Molly takes a swig of her drink and slaps some money on the bar. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving till one of you men starts acting in a manly fashion. Simms puts a hundred dollar bill on the counter. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just get this over with. One ball, one swing, one gull. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy? Tin Cup still sits, head half buried at the bar. He's never passed up such an opportunity, but he's pretty low. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the man. He turns from his bar stool, glances at the situation. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One swing?   Four to one odds. SIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it ten to one. Stick it up your ass. I'm leading the Open. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're talking! Manly men! Whoas! From the barside gallery. Tin Cup rises and someone hands him a club. Suddenly there's a crowd, including Gary McCord who's been watching from the far end of the bar. He grabs a seltzer hose as if it's a mike and begins announcing. McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He's looking at thirty yards of bar and grill, an opening through the French doors, forty yards of patio umbrellas, a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hundred yards of water, and a lonely pelican sitting out there in a 15 mile an hour breeze, south by southwest... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll probably try to shut down a four iron -- no, he's selected his trusty seven iron... Tin Cup steps up to a ball lying on the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of a thin lie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats all that deep rough you were in today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fore in the grill! Fore on the patio! You're the legend, boss... Tin Cup suddenly backs off the swing and turns to Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and hit the ball. McCORD (on "mike")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ledge still has to be thinking about that brutal, ego-sapping, manhood-robbing eighty-three he buried himself under yesterday. I mean, that's just an avalanche of golf swings, a landslide, a pyroclastic flow --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... 98   And he swings -- the ball rockets through the hall a clears the open door... The bettors pile from the bar and grill and race to the patio to watch the flight of the ball, as -- It's carrying, it's hooking, it's carrying, then: THWACK! -- It hits the piling!    The SEAGULL lifts off, SCREECHING angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiff, baby, stiff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99    A whoop goes up -- And Simms storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm outta here. You're all nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I musta been blind thinking you were worth a shit, Simmsy! (raucously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinks on me, boys! Helluva shot, Roy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I thinned it a little or that pelican'd be flying around with a Titleist up his ass... This is the old Tin Cup -- and he's in the clubhouse with an eightyfuckingthree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring rain -- Lightning and THUNDERSTORMS.   It pours down on the club and the beat-up RV. Romeo stands outside with an umbrella, dragging on a cigarette, trying to stay warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Molly in bed, lit only by light spilling in from a parking lamp. They make love with enthusiasm, finally wobbling to a stop. Silence, except for the rain.   Until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kinda shanked it, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no... you were great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tempo is everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfection's unobtainable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mighta rushed it on the downswing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over the top a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... well, as Walter Hagen once said -- 'Sex and golf are the only two things you can be bad at and still enjoy...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a mulligan and tee it up again -- They embrace with enthusiasm and start thrashing again.

dialogues.speaker: BACK OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Romeo's patience is getting thin.   He pounds on the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys done yet? This is no time for a marathon... The rain keeps coming down.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Galleries line fairways and fill stands. The course is wet, the skies threatening, but play is underway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM NANTZ in the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is struggling to come out, the course is drying up, and in case you're just joining us, the leaders have just reached the ninth hole because of delayed starting times -- (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- David Simms is clinging to a one shot lead over Peter Jacobsen... but the real story is out on sixteen where a driving range pro who shot an opening eighty-three is making a run at perhaps the most legendary round of golf in Open history, Johnny Miller's sixty-three at Oakmont -- Ben Wright is in the tower at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sixteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Ben Wright's voice as Tin Cup marks his ball on the green. A small gallery has begun to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone was ever to make a run at what is the most storied number in Open history, Miller's sixty- three, it would be today when the rain has softened the greens, enabling the players to take dead aim at the flags. Still, the unswerving courage of an unknown driving range pro from Salome has raised that humble journeyman from the ashes of an ignominious eighty-three to wave a mighty fist at the pantheon of golf's immortals. This man, this Roy McAvoy has laid siege to the record book by birdieing the first seven holes. A brave par from the water at eight, and a glorious birdie three at the daunting twelfth, another at thirteen... Tin Cup gets his read, and steps up to putt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... this putt to go ten under for the day... Tin Cup putts -- When the ball is still two feet from the hole, Tin Cup raises his putter in triumph... and sure enough, the ball drops in the hole.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Golf fans stream from other fairways to catch up as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup knocks his approach to within six feet of the cup. The swelling gallery at the green roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doreen is behind the till. The regulars and several customers crowd the counter, staring up at the TELEVISION as Dewey rushes in from his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said on the radio he was ten under --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh!!! Silence, everyone watching the TV, everyone starting to contort in body-English, then: A joyous roar -- Tin Cup's putt went down.    Earl twirls with glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's shooting the lowest round ever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And eighteen's a par five. A birdie there, he shoots sixty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta go, boys. We gotta get us on a Continental Trailways and find this damn place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MONITOR shows Tin Cup approaching his ball in the fairway. Ken Venturi is commentating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McAvoy's hit another big drive, but this is not a shot he wants to get aggressive with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Romeo survey the shot -- a long downhill carry over a lake to a slightly elevated green. A shot similar to the one he pulled off at the best-ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-sixty to carry, Roy. You got to lay up, man. I don't care how good you swinging. You got to lay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: up. Tin Cup looks at the iron Romeo proffers. He looks back at the shot, throws some grass in the air, testing the wind. He looks at the gallery, the lake, the green, the whole grand setting... and then: He locates Molly behind the gallery ropes, watching.    S makes a little charging gesture with her fist. And: Tin Cup reaches defiantly past Romeo and pulls out the three wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venturi and Nantz watch Tin Cup set up to play the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His adrenalin's gotten the better of him, Jim. If he lays up he takes bogey out of play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if he knocks this ball in the water he could make seven or eight. And he still has to think about making the cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, every golf fan in America is pulling for him. 111   Wearing that look, the look of eagles, Tin Cup addr his ball... And he swings -- The ball arches off his club, the gallery roars, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. ... Tin Cup drops the three wood on his bag, even as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carry, honey!    Please!   Carry!

dialogues.speaker: LAKE
dialogues.text: The ball plunks in the water inches short of dry land. The GALLERY GROANS.

dialogues.speaker: BACK UP FAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Tin Cup smiles at Molly with chagrin but not defeat.    H turns to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell. You ride 'er till she bucks you or you don't ride at all. I can save par from here. Tin Cup hits a wedge to within five feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up an' down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup is on the dais, fielding questions from REPORTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you go from shooting an eighty-three one day to a record- breaking sixty-two the next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn't from clean living... Laughter from the reporters.       Reporter #1 follows up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you had to do it again, would you still go for the green on eighteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I'll go for it tomorrow and I'll go for it Sunday, cuz I didn't come here to play for no second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup, Molly, Romeo all asleep -- In the same bed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: showing Simms -8 through twelve, Jacobsen -7 through fourteen and McAvoy -7 through seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge gallery lines the fairway and girds the green as Tin Cup approaches his ball in the middle of the fairway. The fans holler "You da man" at Tin Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nantz and Venturi in the booth. Tin Cup is on the monitor, arriving at his ball. We hear SHOUTS from the GALLERY, encouraging him to go for the green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same shot he knocked in the water yesterday. And the thing for him to do right now is to tune out the gallery, rein in his emotions, and forget what he said in yesterday's interview. He has to lay up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo palms the seven iron, waiting for Tin Cup to decide on his play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the three wood. Romeo picks up some grass and flips it in the air.   It blows away from the green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's wind up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
