dialogues.text: The announcers see Tin Cup taking out the three wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he hasn't shown an ounce of fear all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't courage, Jim. This is inexperience, pure and simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup steps up to his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for Venturi, up there in the booth, thinking I should lay up... (addressing his ball)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... He swings and holds the pose. He caught the ball perfectly -- it sails high and true into the luffing breeze, the GALLERY ROARS, and... ... the ball drops, SPLOOSH! into the WATER, a couple feet short of dry land. The GALLERY GROANS.`

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Staring amazed, almost betrayed, that his ball didn't carry the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a long fucking ways. (holds out his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme another ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a water hazard. You go up there and take a drop. Try to save par like you did yesterday. Tin Cup's eyes blink with thought as Romeo's words get through to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.    What the hell was I thinking? And he starts down to the water. A THUNDEROUS OVATION greets his approach, and he raises his hat to salute the fans saluting him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup snarls at the impudent question of Reporter #3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saved par, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to understand your thinking. You were in the same spot on eighteen yesterday without a headwind and you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I can knock it on from there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seemed like a low-percentage shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I! Look at me. I'm playing for... (points at his sew-on patches)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Rio Grande Short-Haul Trucking, Brink and Brown Sanitation, First State Bank of Salome, Wally's Smokehouse... You think a guy like me bothers to think about the percentages? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low-rent roadside cafe specializing in waffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup, Molly and Romeo study the menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some money from the pelican bet -- why don't we go somewhere fancy and celebrate -- get ready for the final round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to celebrate yet. Plus these are my people. I'm a waffle house guy -- gotta stay in touch with that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus he needs his carbohydrates --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the boys from Salome was in town -- this is where they'd be... The boys from Salome walk in -- with Doreen, all looking like hell from the long bus trip. They're ecstatic to see Tin Cup and Romeo. CLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The legend! EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn, we been driving for two days to help you in the last round -- JOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw the Winnebago outside -- we're starving... DEWEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-two!    Sixty-two! TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're home now! ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys a sight for sore eyes. We so damn sick of guys in blazers and slacks that don't wrinkle. It ain't natural 'round here... DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Roy -- we're with you all the way. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doreen, meet Dr. Griswold... er, Molly... my shrink -- MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ex-shrink. (matter-of-factly) We're sleeping together now so I can't be his therapist. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knew what? DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, dear. Good luck. (looking around) Say, I have a little extra cash -- why don't we go somewhere fancy and celebrate -- y'know, kinda get

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ready for the final round? But the Regulars overwhelm her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Waffle House, Doreen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I been dreaming of waffles for 1800 miles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got a waffle house in Odessa just about like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odessa?   It's in Midland, ain't it?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's in Odessa. They all pull up chairs and settle in for a long evening at the Waffle House. Tin Cup leans back in his chair, turns to Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just don't get much better than this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the man, Cup, you the man... Romeo leans over to Doreen amidst the chaos and speaks with suave elegance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking particularly lovely this evening... the coif is extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you... Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All twelve of them are asleep or nearly so in the R.V., sprawled on and over every surface. Much snoring.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Her face close to Tin Cup's.    Both awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nervous about tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm nervous. So's everybody else. But I only gotta come and catch Simms. Sixty-seven guys gotta come and get me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   Except for the random snore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't always be like this... y'know... with me... surrounded by all these guys... snoring... a stripper ex-girlfriend on the floor... my caddie sleeping next to her... all of us damn near broke... won't always be like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her finger over his mouth gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it will... yes it will... and it's okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup slips out of the trailer -- Romeo follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup hitting golf balls alone, except for the faith- ful Romeo, getting ready for the final round of the U.S. Open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly serves coffee to the regulars.     She's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of you is the bookie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all are, but Earl's the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the odds that Roy will win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas has him at ten to one. They're sure he's gonna self-destruct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those sound good to me -- I want you to place a bet for me. Five thousand nine hundred dollars on Tin Cup to win. They stare nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your nestegg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a bad idea, honey -- we love him, but he's gonna fuck- up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said put it all on Roy.    Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't let you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys -- Silence.   Molly's in charge.    She hands them a roll of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it all on Tin Cup. Earl reluctantly takes the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup hits putts, intense, focused.    Peter Jacobsen works his way over to Tin Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking a little tight, Ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta got too much sleep last night. How you choking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just got one thought in my head. Ten under. That's my number. Tin Cup looks up, amused by the gamesmanship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's ever been ten under for the Open, not even Nicklaus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Ledge. Not even Nicklaus. And he moves off to putt. Tin Cup drops a couple balls on the green to putt, and: A ball rolls past them and into a hole.   Tin Cup looks over and sees Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Roy, can't believe I didn't see you with all that high-priced endorsement crap you're flaunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's always been your problem, Dave. You don't think about winning; you just want to look good. (turns away to putt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing is, this ain't a beauty pageant. (turns back, getting in Simms' face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it ain't a rain-shortened Quad Cities or a Greater Greensboro you can back into. This is you'n me, pal. This is match-play, and this time you ain't getting no three shots.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A large gallery surrounds the tree and lines the fairway as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the honor in the final pairing, from Salome, Texas, Mr. Roy McAvoy. Boisterous applause.   Tin Cup tips his cap and nods at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Simms, his pairing in this the final twosome of the final round of the U.S. Open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairways and greens, Dave... and don't forget to wave as I blow by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean blow up? Like you always do? And Tin Cup moves to the tee. His hand shakes worse than it did the first day as he tees his ball. Stepping back to line up his shot, he peers down the fairway through a narrow corridor of faces. A daunting sight. He edges over to Romeo and tautly whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Bet me a buck I don't put it in the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, good. (going to tee off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puts things back in perspective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup looks at his ball, almost invisible in the deep rough. He tries to locate the green beyond the trees that surround him. In golf parlance, he's in jail. He selects a club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way you going? Tin Cup points over the trees.   Romeo grimaces.   Tin Cu addresses the shot. Then: Tin Cup swings -- the ball flutters weakly out of the rough and disappears into the branches of a bushy tree, dropping eventually next to its trunk, and:

dialogues.speaker: LEADER BOARD
dialogues.text: A scorer changes the number beside Tin Cup's name from -7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to -5.   Simms is still -7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup arrives on the tee where Simms now has the honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice double, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep making pars, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take eighteen of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will own you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly and Doreen stand together behind the big gallery. Molly is using a cardboard periscope to look over the gallery to the green. Doreen is on her tip-toes but all she can see are the backs of heads. A swell of cheers builds, then turns to groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Tin Cup ran it five feet past. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he get the name 'Tin Cup'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He played catcher on the high school baseball team. The star pitcher had this big-league curve, and not all his pitches hit Roy in the mitt. Finally, you gotta respect a man's doggedness. You know? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team decided Tin Cup sounded better than Clank. Molly puts down the periscope at that remark, and hands it to Doreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Clank''s not a good name for a man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doreen looks through the periscope.

dialogues.speaker: TIN CUP
dialogues.text: lining up a putt.   She pans over to Romeo helping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Molly... have you ever had a Latin lover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regulars study the board -- the scruffiest lot ever seen at an Open. Next to them stand a group of U.S.G.A. officials, all in neat, matching blazers. The contrast is thrilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boy's in trouble... ya think he's chokin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boy don't choke. He fucks up but he don't choke... The scorer changes the number beside Tin Cup's name to -- -4. Simms is -7, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wright looks at the monitor where Tin Cup stands among some trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is disaster for McAvoy. After losing three shots to par in the first four holes, he should have just taken iron off the tee to get the ball in play. Does he have any shot at all, Gary McCord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's ball lies on dirt next to the trunk of a tree. He surveys his options. Behind him, wearing a headset, McCord analyzes the situation for the TV viewers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is definite jail. This is life without parole. His only chance to stage a jail-break is go at the ball left-handed and hope he can somehow snake it back into the fairway, and save par from there. Tin Cup glares balefully back at McCord. Then he walks over to a nearby tree, and surveys the line to the green from it. He walks back for his ball, turns to McCord... and we see that familiar fierceness aflame in Tin Cup's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty bucks says I knock it on... with a seven iron. And he selects the seven iron, addresses the ball right- and: He swings -- the ball rockets low off his club, and... ... it ricochets off the trunk of a nearby tree, and... ... it bounces up the fairway, skitters past a trap, and trickles onto the green, stopping ten feet from the pin. The gallery goes crazy as Tin Cup steps from the woods collecting his money from McCord while jabbing a taunting finger at Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nantz and Wright stare at the monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That took balls...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Simms ignores Tin Cup's taunt, and lines up his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just Roy being Roy. Just wait him out, Dave. Just make pars. Let him make the mistakes. And he hits his iron to the fat part of the green, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauty, Dave.    Par written all over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scorer posts a -5 next to Tin Cup's name.   Simms is still at -7, and --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Tin Cup intently follows the flight of his iron shot, as: The ball lands near the front of the green, bounces, then rolls, following the contour of the green. It finally stops five feet from the pin. A SWELLING, DEAFENING ROAR from the GALLERY accompanies the unfolding shot, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacobsen looks toward the roar at the ninth green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's making his run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scorer posts a -6 next to Tin Cup's name.   Simms is still at -7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly and Doreen watch Tin Cup drain a putt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still watching Tin Cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why'd you leave him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever dated a guy who actually believes in soul mates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks he's a tough guy, but he's a hopeless romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as the gallery falls silent, she turns to watch Tin Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's firmly-struck putt spins out of the hole.    Th GALLERY GROANS, sharing his agony, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacobsen, pausing to watch, sighs with relief before starting down the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup follows the flight of his approach, and up ahead on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Jacobsen hears the GALLERY ROAR.   He turns to his caddie, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's throwing darts back there. We gotta make birdies, Squeaky, or we are playing for second. And he snatches his driver from the bag, determined to make birdies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scorer posts -7 next to Tin Cup's name.    Simms is still at -7, as is Jacobsen. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacobsen rolls a long putt into the hole, and as the GALLERY CHEERS, he points a finger of challenge back at - Tin Cup waiting in the fairway.   Tin Cup seems to enjoy the taunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Peter. You'n me. That's all there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he selects a club, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's fans, deeply into the beer by now, contort with body-english and holler at the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in there!    Come on!   Go down! They explode with cheers.   Some twirl with glee.   Other exchange high fives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tied for the lead again!    And they're running outta holes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leader board is superimposed on the monitor.    McAvo -8, Jacobsen -8, Simms -7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's come down to the seventy- second hole of this great championship, and the skill and courage of three Texans who have dueled throughout the day for the chance to be crowned Open Champion... Peter Jacobsen is on the fairway at 8 under, McAvoy at the 18th tee is tied at minus 8, and David Simms trails by one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Romeo watch Jacobsen hit his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacobsen's laying up. (turning to Simms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't gonna have that luxury, Dave. Not if you play to win. He moves to the tee, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monitor shows Tin Cup's drive bounding down the middle of the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McAvoy's hit a perfect drive, Ken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure that's good news for McAvoy. With his inexperience, the last thing he needs is an excuse to fool with that water again today.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TEE
dialogues.text: Tin Cup whispers to Romeo as Simms tees up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't catch it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you got to lay up. Simms rips a drive down the middle, the ball landing a little short of Roy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup in the fairway, studying his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So birdie wins it. He looks at Simms, ten yards across the fairway from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You or me, Dave? Simms points to himself. He has a wood in his hands, but he puts the club back and reaches for an iron. Tin Cup edges closer to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's laying up. Birdie to tie, eagle to win, and that gutless wonder's laying up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Par to tie, birdie to win... you lay up too, Roy. You can make birdie laying up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch Simms lay up. Then Romeo offers Tin Cup an iron, hoping he'll take it. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, Romeo? Eagle puts me ten under. No one's ever finished an Open ten under, not even Nicklaus. ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need an eagle. Birdie wins, par ties. (firmly) Hit the lay up. Hole a wedge for goddamn eagle. Tin Cup throws some grass in the air, looks back at the green, the gallery, the whole grand setting... and he seeks out Molly's face in the crowd. He moves over so she can hear him. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is everything, ain't it? This is the choice it comes down to. This is our immortality... ROMEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time to be thinkin' 'immortality,' Cup... time to be thinkin' 7 iron. Molly stands with Doreen, hearing Tin Cup's words. Thrilled and terrified and spellbound, she finds herself nodding. Doreen, on the other is turning ash-white. DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. This is what always happens. He's going for it. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for it! DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He just needs par to tie! Tell him to lay up! He listens to you! MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for it, Roy! Knock it on! DOREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is why we split up -- he always went for it... MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My problem is I've never been with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a man who went for it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, honey, he's your guy.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: He selects the three wood.    Romeo sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord, he's going for the green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be tragic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup's eyes focus with the look of eagles as he addresses the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One swing, Roy. One good swing. Dollar bills... He swings -- the ball explodes off his club.   Tin Cup holds the pose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're home... Suddenly a gust of wind blows, out of nowhere, and Tin Cup's cap blows off, provoking immediate concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... little gust there, Romes...

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION MONITOR
dialogues.text: Picking up the flight of the ball approaching the green, carried it seems by the swelling roar of the gallery. The ball clears the water... ... and lands at the top of the slope fronting the elevated green. It pops up in the air, lands just past where it hit, and comes momentarily to rest. The gallery roars. And then: The ball starts trickling back down the slope, gaining speed, moving towards the water, even as the gallery screams for it to stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... until finally it disappears into the water with scarcely a ripple.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: He stares first with betrayal, then with anger, and looks at Romeo, who just shrugs, then at Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can still make par from up there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right, Pods, a drop and a stroke, up and down par -- we'll win it in sudden death. But Tin Cup still has the look of eagles. He's staring at the shot he just made, still holding the three wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I nutted that thing. Little gust from the gods cost me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva move you put on that sucker, now let's get up there, take the drop, and make our par, tie Peter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can make this shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Tin Cup throws another ball on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm playing it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your drop and make your par! Tin Cup addresses the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venturi nearly comes out of seat watching Tin Cup take a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: drop from his original lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this. He just took himself out of the tournament with that drop. He could have walked up to the hazard line, saved par with a wedge and forced a playoff with Jacobsen. Now he needs a miracle shot. McCORD (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ken, I'm right behind McAvoy here. And all he said to his caddie was: I can make it across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup swings again -- The ball sails long and true once again, and once again... 158   ... it lands into the hill, bounces once, and trick back into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my.   This is tragic.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Holding his hand out to Romeo, as the gallery murmurs uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme another ball.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO DOREEN AND MOLLY
dialogues.text: watching behind the ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe he's doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can blow the whole tournament!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle he lasted this long...

dialogues.speaker: REGULARS
dialogues.text: waiting at the green, amidst the rest of the gallery who's in shock about Tin Cup's decisions to keep going for it, keep trying to prove a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He done blew a gasket, boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels is definitely falling off now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a miracle while it lasted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup swings a third time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BALL lands SPLOOSH! in the WATER, and...

dialogues.speaker: BACK UP FAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Tin Cup holds out his hand for yet another ball, saying nothing. Romeo hands him another ball. Tin Cup unloads another 3-wood.    Another splash. Tin Cup holds out his hand again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your last ball, man. If this gets wet, you disqualified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can make it across. Tin Cup snatches the ball from Romeo's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venturi and Nantz can barely look at the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most painful thing I've ever watched. McCORD (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, this is the last ball he has in his bag. If he doesn't finish the hole with it, he can't turn in a card. He'll be disqualified. Venturi and Nantz cover their eyes. Tin Cup unloads another three wood -- another splash.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: He looks at Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: She's just laughing. Romeo tosses down another ball -- Tin Cup launches his fifth attempt to clear the pond. Splash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Roy, what the hell! Let 'er rip!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two are made for each other.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: This is still all business to him.    He sets his jaw, addresses the shot, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar bills... He swings -- another perfect shot... but this time the wind relents a knot, and:

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: clears the water, clears the slope, hits the front of the green, rolls up toward the pin, and drops in the hole. The gallery goes berserk!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TIN CUP
dialogues.text: Raising his three wood aloft in triumph, he looks over at Molly and finally cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And when she smiles back, he takes his hat off and walks to the green, to as great an ovation as the game has ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN TELEVISION TOWER
dialogues.text: Venturi and Nantz slump, drained, over their monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Simms sign their cards and get up to leave in unison. Simms turns to Tin Cup and has to shake his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta hand it to you, Roy.   When you go down, you go down in flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday you can tell your grandchildren you finished second in the U.S. Open... (beat) -- just don't tell 'em how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he moves brusquely past Simms and out of the tent, congratulating Tubbs, the winner, as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good job, Tubbsy... you won it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And out of the scorer's tent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roar goes up from the milling fans as Tin Cup emerges. He tries to smile, but it's all dawning on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God... I just gave away the Open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then McCord is there, shoving a mike in Tin Cup's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ledge, I know it's tough to talk right now, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not difficult to talk... it's difficult to explain... I coulda laid up and still won. I made a twelve on the last hole of the U.S. Open. You know how much money that cost me? McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cost you a bundle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get outta here. McCORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the greatest 12 I ever saw. Back to you, Jim... Tin Cup exits the scorers' tent and runs into the regulars -- They're beaming, undyingly loyal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greatest 12 I ever saw... you crunched that dog, baby... gorgeous shot, etc... He looks up and there's Molly -- He stops short.    They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, I'm an idiot. I gave away the Open. The one time in my life I know the play is to hit the lay up -- my whole life and future and career on the line, and I still can't make myself do it. I am a twisted human being and a cautionary tale. And I guess I'm a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   A magnificent fool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mosquitoes, pools of light, the TRACTOR CHUGS around picking up balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo and Doreen eye each other -- locked in a stare of longing and mystery. TANGO MUSIC comes from a BOOM BOX. They begin to move toward each other in a tango step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tin Cup and Molly are sitting, feet up, a couple Lone Star beers beside them, just taking in the warm Texas night. Her head rests on his shoulder. The world at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people don't like West Texas but I think it's the most beautiful place on earth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has its charms... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, by finishing in the top 15 at the Open you qualified to be in it next year --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, I didn't know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking with your game you should go back to the Qualifying School, try to get out on tour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I wouldn't see you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I picked up a whole bunch of new clients at the Open. Lotta guys on the tour said if I could do that much for you, imagine what I could do for them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lotta head cases out there, you could make a bundle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sleep in the Winnebago at night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know... a man goes through what I've gone through, he's supposed to learn something. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to figure out what I learned. Did I learn anything? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're learning some discipline and self-control... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that there's a time in life to play it safe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great,   Roy... and I'm learning how to listen   to the tuning fork, throw caution   to the wind, and take crazy risks I   never thought were possible... TIN CUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Molly, when did you ever take a crazy risk? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fell for you...

dialogues.speaker: LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: A desolate driving range outside of Salome, Texas. Bugs, trucks passing in the night, and a tiny RADIO SENDING GEORGE JONES across the plains.
